review: Love Park is an expansive park in Downtown Philadelphia. There are many sights and monuments. You can spend all day or limit yourself to an hour or so. I would wear good walking shoes and bring a camera to have your picture made under the "Love Park" sign. There are many street vendors with drinks and snacks or feel free to bring your own bottle of water. My husband, Son and myself will be going back for sure on our next trip to Philadelphia!

After being pickpocketed in front of Macy's Philly and biking consolant but cheerful back to my car in Fairmount Park to grab more cash -- the only thing now left in my name, I stumbled upon something that totally brightened up my visit: couples of all types, lining up anxiously for a memorable shot in front of Robert Indiana's Love Sculpture.

There were couples, madly in love, young and old, friends, platonic and borderline lovers, some rekindling the fire after many decades, their progeny now with many children of their own, wanting to know how the fire sparked that caused Mom and Dad to become ONE.

The image of couples romancing, the line never stopping, made me truly realize that this was too good of an opportunity to let slip by. In life, you either just live by, or you LIVE in it. I chose the latter.

I set up a camera on the platform behind by the water fountain to film time lapse to prove once and for all that while I was there, the line never stopped -- truly all day and night -- there's always some couple approaching or waiting in line to get their picture-perfect shot. If not lovers, there are skaters -- one or the other, people tend to flock to and admire the simple but meaningful iconic image made famous by Robert Indiana.

To complete the all encompassing emotionally powerful scene, I decided to chat to couples and ask them two simple but sound questions: 1) Where did you guys meet; 2) What are your plans in the City of Brotherly Love.

The posted video is the results. I hope you find it enlightening as it was for me. Actually the story from one of the couples resoundingly melted my heart. My heart is still in tattered pieces as I mindfully revisit this scene.
This is also known as JFK Plaza. For some reason, I was expecting more. Bigger letters.... something. Maybe it would have been better if the fountains were operating.
Not much to see but the fact that it's love park is enough. It takes a minute to get one of the other tourists to snap a pic of you but it's worth it.

It was great to learn the history of this park where sometimes you'll be treated to a musical concert depending on the time of year. The "O" is off centered; but the designer often times have said that the reason for the off centered "O" is because Love is not perfect!

If you are into walking through trash, urine, and feces. Walking around the homeless sleeping on benches, harrassment by beggars, and dodging angry youth on skateboards, then this is the place to go. The city really needs to clean this place up.
This iconic side while on the smaller side is good to stop by and take a snapshot on your way to some of the bigger sites like the art museum.

Love Park (aka JFK Plaza) is fairly center in Philly and an attraction you'll likely walk past many of times. We walked from our hotel to the museums and past Love Park many times ourselves.

Although a nice photo (and famous one), the LOVE is actually very small. They make it seem large in photos, but really it’s not very large. It’s in a small park in the center of the street...yes there are homeless, but there are lots of people hanging around (including tons of tourists and weddings taking photos). Never felt unsafe.

I would not go out of my way to see this by any means....but if you are walking past it (as you likely will be) it’s worth stopping for a quick photo.
Homeless people constitute a hefty minority here and use the fountain for bathing. The water smells like sewage. Don't waste your time.

We visited this place with our 2 year daughter on Sunday eveniing. we liked the fountain and LOVE statue but felt very unsafe at the place..it was very dirty, many homeless people sleeping around..people standing to take your photo and asking for money...some people starring at kid...we felt very unsafe didn't even bothered to spend more time..
Beautiful landscaping here, highly recommended. It is The icon of the city, a must see when you visit Philly!

I made a point to visit Love Park to see the LOVE statue and it was worth it. I ended up sitting in the park for about an hour enjoying some Starbucks and watching people flood in and out taking romantic and funny pictures with the statue. The whole experience gave me the warm fuzzies. Nice to see that something this simple brings such joy to so many people. I ended up buying s Tshirt with LOVE on it later that day just to remember the experience :)

The fountain was a nice spot to soak your weary feet after a day of sightseeing. And yes, the LOVE letters are a great spot to have your picture taken with a loved one, but I would've felt a bit uneasy if I were alone, since there were several homeless people cooling off on some vents that surround the park.
Crime rate in Philadelphia makes this poor rating.
A picture of the "Love" sculpture is a must but this part is usually hustling and bustling. It's a great place to grab lunch from a lunch truck and chill.
its certainly a beautiful place, with a lovely view of the streets of Philadelphia! but i must let you know, in winter there aint no love! what you see in summer is not what you see n winter.
It's a must see for any visitor. Get your picture with the statue, wonder around a bit, then move on to some other Philly favorites!
Must stop by for a few shots... Even if you are not in love.

Whenever you see anything for Philly, the LOVE sculpture is always there somewhere. My boyfriend was visiting from Finland, so I had to show him the iconic little thing. We took a walk over to JFK Plaza to look around and get some pictures.

The sculpture itself is smaller than you'd expect, but it's still nice to see it. The Christmas tree in the plaza was beautiful, and there was a strange Kraft Macaroni sculpture there as well :) The plaza was dirty and full of trash, with plenty of homeless people sleeping everywhere, not something my boyfriend is used to and he felt unsafe there.

All in all, it's worth seeing once, before you go to all the other excellent attractions the city has to offer.
loved the little christmas village that was set up around the perimeter of the park! it was such a nice surprise!

Love Park is where the somewhat famous Love Statue resides. The one with the tilted "O". Anyway at Christmas time they put up a huge tree in the fountain and transform the area to a Christmas Village. Many vendors are there selling one of a kind goods, crafts, and food. It is a nice place to visit during the holiday season.

Love Park (actually formally named JFK Plaza) is a popular and iconic spot in Center City Philly. It is directly across the street to the east from Suburban Station, a rail hub, and there is a parking garage directly beneath the park. There is also a Philly Phlash bus stop on the south side of the park, where visitors can board and ride to a myriad of the city's most famous destinations for a small fee. (The bus runs from April to the end of October.) The City Hall subway stop of both the Broad Street and Market Street lines is right across the street. Bounded by 15th and 16th Streets and JFK Blvd. and Arch Street, diagonally to the northwest from City Hall, it is a place where Center City residents and workers enjoy sitting during lunch hour, where people-watching is a favorite pastime, and where all sorts of interesting --- and yes, sometimes unsavory --- things happen.

During the summer, there are noontime concerts of all kinds, from DJs playing dance music that has passersby stopping to join in the dancing, to cool jazz or folk. There's always something to listen to and enjoy. The water in the fountain is often dyed different colors for different causes. It is a great spot to people-watch, read, walk the dog, or just look at the summer flowers.

The view of the Benjamin Franklin Parkway and City Hall from Love Park is pretty spectacular; you can see all the way up the Parkway to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, and, in the opposite direction, you can view the gorgeous City Hall's magnificent architecture. There are photo opportunities at every turn!

Skateboarding is prohibited in the park now, but this law is pretty much ignored, as young skateboarders are there when the crowds diminish. On weekends, and especially during the winter when the fountain is turned off, skateboarders abound, and they are fascinating to watch.

There are many homeless people in Philadelphia, and some stake their spots at Love Park. For the most part, they are harmless and do nothing more annoying than panhandling. I would not suggest walking through the park after dark unless there are a lot of other people there, as it is not particularly well-lit at night and there is not a strong police presence most of the time. But the park is generally safe.

From Thanksgiving until Christmas Eve, the park is home to the Christmas Village, a lovely little German-inspired village of vendors' huts, with everything from German chocolates and local honey to handmade goods and artwork.

There is also a year-round information and souvenir building on the site. It is round and looks like a flying saucer. There are green, grassy areas for lazing, cafe tables and chairs by the information building, benches, trees,and beautiful flower gardens throughout the park. There are varying levels in the park and it isn't particularly wheelchair friendly, except right at fountain level (entering from the 16th and Arch Street area), or by entering at either 15th or 16th and JFK Blvd. and not going down to the fountain level, although there are plans to revamp and make it more handicap-accessible in the near future.

Love Park is close enough to the big tourist destinations in the city --- the art museum, the Rodin Museum, the Museum of Natural History, The Franklin Institute, Reading Terminal Market, and Rittenhouse Square --- that it shouldn't be missed.

Growing up in the 80's and 90's skateboarding I was excited to finally go see the iconic Love Park. While it still looks the same as remember from the videos it feels dead. When I was young I would have done anything to go visit this park and watch and feel the electricity in the area. Now its just a area for homeless people and their waste. Shame on the city for letting this happen. They had a chance to put skateboard guidelines in place to keep the youth in the are involved and keep the area alive. Now it is scary at night and scary in the day as well. Hopefully the next time my family goes my kids can skate there hassle free. Come on Philadelphia either clean it up right or give it to a group of young people who will take care of it.
The locals and the Occupy Philadelphia crowd makes this place scary

I found the sculpture after walking around city center doing some exploring. I honestly thought it was a copy or some like that, because it so much smaller than I anticipated. I don't mean to be overly negative, I guess I just expected something more iconic. Since this was my first visit to Philly I am glad I saw it but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it again. Philadelphia has some great outdoor art, this certainly wasn't one of my favorites.
Great park, even though they don't allow the skateboarders or occupy folks there anymore. It was way better when it was a more liberal place
Awesome view of City Hall and the Art Museum, too. Walking Distance from Rittenhouse Square and Reading Terminal (but they're in opposite directions).
Unsafe and unclean....plenty of better parks in the city.

This used to be a great place to hang out on a summer afternoon and enjoy a spot of people watching while having a brown bag lunch. Then the skateboarder crowd showed up and it became a cool place to watch kids do their thing. Ar-t Christmas time it is a huge open air Euro-style market. Now it is populated by down and outs as the sun sets and you can;t help but find yourself scratching yourself after rising from one of the benches. Hinky. Yuk. I rate it very good because of its sight lines and because I have Hope as well as Love for my town. This needs to bounce back.
This is a great spot to start exploring the Parkway Museums District.
Nothing to do here other than take the iconic picture - but that is the exact reason you visit.

So much fun! :) I wanted to go here for the famous Love Statue but there was so much more to see than I expected! Right across from the Love Statue there was a plaza with all sorts of fun statues from dominoes, monopoly, chess, bingo, etc. Great place to take fun pictures! Absolutely recommend taking a walk through it while you're in the city.
Best seen at night when crowds are thin and few. Also the christmas village during the holidays is a must.
Great views-- and iconic. Tourists shouldn't miss out on this!
I like this park. It's great people watching and a very nice place to lunch in the nice weather.
If you're in Philly check out the Love Park. I also love the oversized game board pieces. Both sites make for great pictures!
If you want to see the iconic "love" sculpture then come, not too much else in this park, but not that far out of way from downtown philly.
it was fun...... n i love taking pic there........
When you work in center city, its nice to relax at lunchtime in love park.

The park itself is small. Homeless sleeping on benches. I wanted to take my daughter's picture in front of the statue and a man came over to us and said he would take our picture together. I handed my camera, he took a couple of picutes gave me my camera back and asked for money for doing this. I said thank you, but I wasn't paying him and we walked away. We left the park feeling uncomfortable, but as we were walking the outer edge of the park he was doing it to other people and they were giving him money. Later on at the Rocky Statue we saw him there doing the same thing! We go to NYC often and I have never had people do anything like this. Also the police presence was REALLY lacking.
Close to city center, walkable, smaller than I thought, but still great to see! Thought it was going to be sitting on the ground, but it was on a platform.
The statue is situated in the center and you can easily see it if you walk to Museum of Art or to the City Hall.

I didn't know this famous sculpture by city hall was so small!! When I first saw it, I thought it must be a model of the real one! That's why it's good to travel and see things in person. Perspective.

Great place in Philly for that "Kodak moment"!! I was a little surprised by the large groups of people who congregate here and just seem to hang out. Was confronted twice by the same guy wanting to take our family's picture - didn't really care for that, but there weren't any other problems.
The actual letters are smaller than I imagined. There is also lots of homeless people nearby this park.
I know this is a site seeing spot for out of towners but watch out for all the homeless people that hang there. Can be kinda creapy.
The fountain and the iconic Philly monument here are the perfect spot to grab some lunch and sit & eat with a friend or on a date. Love this section of Philly.
Took a stroll through the park. It was one of the places listed to see - when new to the city. I enjoyed it - and it was also a great spot to people watch.

If you're wandering around north of market street and need a place to rest, love park is a good place to take a breather. If you're there during the week during the morning or lunch time you should also definitely check out the food carts - the burger cart in particular is very good and though I've never eaten at the pizza cart, the long lines for it attest to its popularity. Otherwise, there's not much to see/do in the park. You might want to consider checking out sister cities park on the other side of ben franklin parkway - I thin its more charming and there's an adorable cafe in the center of it now, Milk and Honey that's open till at least 7pm.

My one girlfriend, during her bachelorette party, we took her to this site and about 10 of us interrupted these few skaters so we could take a few photos in front of this great art piece!! It's definitely a memory she won't forget

Walked with food to here from Reading Terminal Market to eat. There is a nice big fountain to look at to get peace from the busy downtown area. You should definitely walk through the park during your visit.
every needs their picture with this iconic statue. The view down JFK blvd is nice. It is always really really crowded here though. And also littered with the homeless.
There's always something fun happening in Love Park, especially on weekdays.

With that said you have to come to love park if only to take a photo in front of the sign. Yes, you'll see homeless people, derelicts, street peddlers, break dancers, skateboarders and business men/women cutting through a short cut to get back to their offices.

The good thing is every is harmless and enjoying their slice of the city so come on down to love park

Not quite sure why this is such a landmark. It's a very small statue in a very busy park. We didn't even bother to stop. There is so much more to see in Philly than this, and I wouldn't waste my time on it.
Full of homeless people and lout. Dirty people swimming in the fountain and the water mist sprays anyone nearby. City version of "people of WalMart"

Seen the fake one in NYC. This one is far better. Very helpful guys move you to the front of the line to take pictures for a small tip. It is worth it. Trust me. Don't be the schmuck standing at the back of the crowd, you will never get a picture that way.
Not impressed. You can literally stand underneath the sign. Busy park, questionable people hanging around for those that aren't used to "big city" inhabitants. not even a good photo op.

A Philadelphia landmark, it was fun to see a bride and groom visit the LOVE sign for a photo op on their big day.

However, it was unappealing seeing kids of all ages (some in their twenties or thirties) cross into the fountain and splash around. What a sight, definitely took away from the beauty of the place.
Kids had a very nice time, and it was something nice to stop and see for the whole family. Great picture place too.

Yesterday the skaters were videotaping and it was a little crowded as people were standing in the fountain. The park more like a courtyard of a building and the Love sculpture is small. It's really like a rest stop when walking from museums area to downtown. It was surrounded by beggars, vagrants, and creepy people as we walked through. Get in line to have your picture taken in front of the sculpture.

Its where skateboarders go and tourists take pics but I see alota people who have the love park tat on them n it don't seem like a bad idea cuz it represents where I was born n raised like Will said hahahaha but beware of being hit up left n right for directions and asked for change by bums

This park is inhabited by homeless people and vagrants. This is not a place that tourists should go after the sun goes down. It was a few blocks from Logan Sq where our hotel was and the walk is nice getting there but the park is intimidating and scary. Vandals had spray painted the elbow macaroni on the other side of the park. We noticed the next day it was painted over. Daylight this park is great and bustling with people. Just beware of the homeless and undesirables.

First we went to Macy's to see the light show which is great then walked around the streets christmas shopping then walked the Love Park which had vendors set up with tents, walked around and spent a lovely day in Philadelphia. Took some great pictures under the LOVE sign for memories.

user_base: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
review: People in line to take pictures with the monument.The waterfall is a great backdrop to the statue. There was even a couple posted to take your picture for a small fee.

I came into center city Philadelphia the other day and got off the train near this spot which is also called JFK Plaza. It is a nice little block square park that has the famous Robert Indiana "LOVE" sculpture, a Visitors Center, a lovely water fountain in the center that is dyed different colors at times for different events. Some nice places to sit and relax or eat lunch--there were 3 terrific food trucks parked that day. The park is between15th and 18th streets, and JFK Blvd. and Arch St. There is a parking garage under the park and you can get there easily by local transportation--it is right across the street from Suburban Station, a stop on the regional rail line.
"Love" statue is a favorite place of couples to take pictures, but the surrounding area is not that nice - there is a lot of homeless people, and I just don't feel safe there
i think love park is a good place to be because my sister went there once with her school and she think it was fun so she took a class picture
Its just a unique piece of art, and a great place to have your picture taken. Its right in the middle of the city, near the Arts and great restaurants as well.
A nice little park in the middle of Philadelphia, with the iconic LOVE statue. A great photo opportunity and a place to relax (and cool off in the fountain!)

My son loved it and got himself all wet wading. I wasn't sure if there was a sign forbidding that but many people were wading including adults and no one seemed to stop them.

This is a very crowded park. Everyone wants to be there to take a picture with the LOVE sign. NYC has a bigger sign though.

This park has a beautiful fountain and the famous Love statue, but it has a huge homeless population. We had to walk near it as it got dark after dinner, and it was scary. I was with my three kids and definitely didn't feel comfortable.
Though I've heard there are movies & such there on summer evenings, on a non-event spring day, it's just a place to pass through. Meh.

Its an icon of the city, and you will probably just come across it anyway. It's much smaller than I thought it would be and it's just in an average small park. There were Xmas markets on when we visited, so that was cute. If you want your photo together, there is generally someone hanging around that will do it for you, for a tip of course!
And if you ever used to skateboard go to pay your respects to this legendary spot. Other than that it's just park, but it's easy to get to and worth the stop for a philly icon.

Nice little park in the center of town. We checked out the Christmas Village after the Thanksgiving Day parade. There was a nice mix of crafts, arts, and gifts. We didn't expect to Christmas shop while here, but we purchased two gifts.

Get to the JFK... or love park on Ben Franklyn Parkway
ON our short visit we walk all the way to the park, it was really nice to sit down a bit.
All though it was a hot sunny day so we need it some shade.
We got to the PKK for some waters and walked to the nearest irish pub/restaurant...
The ample park in the center of town its nice but there were lots homeless people on the area a bit unfortable for a visit. They were on their own bussiness but as a first time visit we felt that we shouldnt stay long.

This is a must visit to your tour list on Philly.

Love Park is a great place to walk around and take photos. I've went a few times with my boyfriend, family and friends who have visited from out of town. The only downside is that a lot of homeless people stay around it to ask for money from tourists.

If you're a visitor you need to get your picture taken in front of the Indiana Sculpture and probably a friendly man will volunteer immediately, asking a dollar afterwards. It's worth it, but not a place you'll hang around for long, so go immediately to Rittenhouse Square if you want a sense of quiet park life in Philly.

Nice to see some green space amid all the high rises in Philly, but this park is unfortunately filled with a lot of homeless folks which makes one feel not so safe and like you are interfering with someone's personal "home" space!
great place to stop for a picture, but after that not much to do. People looking to take your picture for money are usually standing around as well.
Such a nice place to go. Look some pictures with my fiance here and used it for our Save-the-Date! Very nice for a fall day stroll!

It's a great park and it's neat to see and have your picture taken with the love statue. We went once early in the day and it was great. We went a second time in the evening and it was jam packed with skateboarders. It felt like we were going to get a deck in the ankle any minute and it didn't make for the best pictures.

Well, it was packed with people - really packed - and there was no parking to be found, so we had to settle for driving around the area two (or was it three?) times looking for some place to park so we could get closer. Couldn't find a spot to park unfortunately, so we drove around and said - OK - we saw it -- and headed over to the museum area. Not really sure if it would have been worth getting out of the car or if it just would have been a silly touristy thing to do. It was Valentine's Day, so we had to give it a shot :)
Go downtown at Christmas every year to visit Christmas displays and see the LOVE fountain frozen over.

Besides the famous LOVE sculpture, there isn't much special about Love Park. There is a nice round fountain with a seating area around it. In the summer children will put their feet in. It is steps away from Suburban Station, so it is worth at least walking through. There are food trucks and carts around that serve some great cheap eats. Sometimes there is special entertainment, but it is just mediocre.
Dirty, dangerous and gross. This potentially beatiful area is not vibrant, not clean, not friendly and not well utilized. The city needs to tear this chunk of old real estate up and rebuild it.

With all the beautiful places we have in the city and near by, I don’t really get why people rate this place as one of the main or most important attractions/places to visit in Philly. I mean, really? The world LOVE is very pretty, of course, but meaningless here. The park is not a big deal in terms of architecture and it doesn’t have any particular historical importance. Besides the surrounding and the park it self are VERY dangerous. It is very well known in Philly that homeless people and robbers hang out there. If what people like is to be photographed with a sing that says LOVE while being robbed this is the place where you should go. I completely dislike it.

Had to do the obligatory photo in this park, but it's much smaller and less exciting than one might imagine. Photo op is great, but don't plan to spend too much time here. I went before Thanksgiving when they were setting up the holiday decorations--looks like it has potential to be more festive and entertaining once that's all set up with lights, etc. but I wasn't awed.

During the holiday season Love Park features a delightful Christmas Village with vendors of crafts and foods from all over the world with a European focus. The mulled wine was very popular, and the German crafts exquisite. Occasional live music performances make this a fun draw for young and old on a December evening. I wish it had stayed open beyond 8 p.m., though.
Very nice place to walk thru some awesome craft vendors. Must see in Philly this time of year. Good food & treats for the family too.

I have not been to Love Park in years and just walking through...after I had to go into the city for training for work...it was awesome. It truly lives up to its name of Love Park...just wish I had my husband there LOL…
We stopped here in November. There were more than 60 vendors selling items. It was nice to walk around the various boths and shop for Christmas Gifts. I got some really good deals!

The fountain area was a great stopping place on a sunny day.

The area is edged with some lovely trees, they seemed to be dropping blossoms which looked good.

Plenty of people having their photo taken with the Love sign.

Crossing this area later at night doesn't feel as comfortable with people loitering and skateboarders flying around with little care for anyone passing

Walked through this park, while the sun shined brightly and a band played live as we walked through. Cute water fountain with pink water, plenty of places to sit, seemed to appeal to old and young alike. People reading, listening to the music, strolling, etc. a nice place to spend an hour or two, or to stop for lunch.

Be realistic, avaerage is a great rating for a sign near a fountain in the middle of Philadelphia. Surrounded by obsolete shops and vendors selling obsolete junk. Should I mention the fact that the homeless and city kids acting like gangsters, and unsupervised make this anyhting but attractive for those with kids.

In the heart of Philadelphia, this park is transformed to a Christmas Village for shopping in the holiday season. Festive crowds, local entertainers and warm cider made the Tree Lighting event very memorable.

I finally made my first visit to Philly a few weeks ago and specifically had on my 2Do list a visit to this park to see live in person the iconic "Love" statue. So do you remember this scene from the move "Spinal Tap" - Nigel Tufnel is in the middle of a performance, waiting for the life-size Stonehenge prop he designed to come down from the rafters to the oohs and ahs of the audience? The only problem being that when he had sketched out the dimensions he accidentally used the notation for inches instead of feet? So my reaction was the same as Nigel's - stunned at how small this actually was. No idea how it got into my head that this would be much larger. Still cool to see, but otherwise not much to do at the park itself, at least the day I visited. Rock N Roll!

Went at Christmas time & they had a Christmas Village there which was very cool. Lots of booths, vendors, food & best of all.......mulled wine! Definitely a fun & worthwhile trip during the Christmas season.

My description in the title is the one that fits the best. Nothing that special maybe if the fountain behind it would be on it would be much more interesting but without it, it just says just:
LO
VE.
Funny to take some pictures for your loved once, you just need to some creativity.

Take your pic next to the statue, get overspray from the fountain (when it warms up), head to the Art Museum or Chestnut Street or South Street.
It's often a little stinky due to the indigents around the edges. Addition of food trucks by the Visitor's center is a plus (16th & JFK corner).
The park itself isn't that special but I really loved the Love sculpture! It is my favorite memory from Philly :)

So pretty and refreshing to go to for lunch in the summer. It is right down the street from the Art Museum and the LOVE sign is great to take pictures at. Every so often they will dye the fountain purple, pink, red, or blue which is so cool to see.
Love park is somewhere that you have to stop at in Philadelphia. HOWEVER- DO NOT go there after dark, it's very seedy.
It's located just northwest of Philadelphia City Hall. We spent a moment hear relaxing by the fountain.

That IS what she said!
The LOVE sign is so small, and it is now on a platform so you aren't able to climb/sit on it.
The water fountain in the background is a nice touch, but it is still pretty much a disappointment.
IF you are going to venture to the park be sure to go in the earlier hours so you are on the correct side of the sun.
If you go in late afternoon the sun is behind you, and it is too dark to see your face in the photo. The day we went the line was fast and people were friendly.
Check out the monopoly game pieces across the street at the municipal building. You can climb and sit on those for more active/fun photos.
We were there on a Sunday afternoon and there seemed to be parking on the street and ample parking garages in the area.
The Masonic Temple is on the other side of the block, so there are other things to do in the area.
Even though I was disappointed, I still wouldn't tell someone not to go.
The LOVE sign is such a Philly thing to do. I guess I would say go, but keep your expectations to a minimum.
And plan to visit the other sites in the immediate area.

We were on the Phlash Trolley and saw this famous sculpture. We stopped just for a photo. We had to wait for other couples who wanted a picture under the Love sign. There was a man there offering to take photos for a small fee or a tip I am sure.

Don't go out of your way to see it since there is not much else there except for the fountain.
Good for a quick stop to take a picture with the sign. There were people actually using the park as it was intended, so this is not a place for tourists. We were there for all of 10 minutes.

Daughter wanted to see the sign, having seen it in a book. We beat the protesters to the park but needed to leave after about two minutes to avoid being swallowed by the chanting crowd.

Seems lovely otherwise, but it's popularity made it a target that day.

We thought that the purple fountain was a neat touch and a picture was definitely necessary in front of the LOVE sign, but we thought the sign would be bigger. It's worth a look, but not necessarily a must-go destination if you're in Philly.
Did the whole tourist picture under the love sign also a cool fountain behind the sign thought it would be a lot bigger

We took a photo under the love statue during our morning run. Dropped in quick and had a photo taken by someone who "didn't really work for the park" but was happy to take tourists pictures for a tip. A little unusual, but she was pleasant enough and did a nice job with the pics. There are also a few geocaches nearby if you're into that.

In Philly, most attractions and museums close at 4 or 5 pm, when the sun is still high in the sky (summer), so I navigate myself to Love Park each day in the early evening to chill. There is really nothing to see besides the big LOVE, but it is definitely great to sit by the fountain, rest your feet and watch the sun goes down.

Growing up we would often visit love for some world class skateboarding, however ever since the x-games was there and they redesigned it to prevent skating it it terrible. Now it is often overrun by crackheads and thrives, great job Philadelphia.

Nice to see and to say that you have been there. But by no means is this park the best I have ever been to.Its interesting, nice to see the LOVE attraction, the park is nice, but too many crowds taking over the park. Not the best feeling I have ever had in a park. Glad I have been though.

The fountain is lovely and the "LOVE" is so cool and iconic but the surrounding area has many sketchy looking people and trash around. Keep your wits about you when you are here.
Great photo op location!
The beauty of the city centre in Philadelphia includes the parks within the skyscrapers. Love Park has a beautiful fountain.

I thought that the visitor center in Love Park was great. We got our trolley tickets there for the Phlash and she helped me with other questions. The Phlash stop is right outside. I did get a photo of the sculpture one day when it was raining, but I never got my photo because of the crowds. Don't remember much more about the park except it has a fountain that people wanted to play in.

Typical tourists, had to stop and snap a shot. Thanks to the local entrepreneur who snapped one group shot. He took a good shot, and probably needed the $1 more than my pocket. Was surprised that it is fairly small.

user_base: New York, New York, United States
review:
The sign was lovely and the water fountain in the back was a nice touch as well

But as we were approaching the sign, this ghetto looking woman came up to us and voluntarily asking if me and my bf needed a pic together. We said no guessing she wanted money

And we saw her asked every couple that came close the love sculpture if they needed a photo together, and everyone got scared by her and refused.

And she hovered over the sign the entire time, so we didn't get to take a pic at all....
Overall, a good place, but unfortunately lots of weird and ghetto people around.

Walking down 15th, there were many beautiful buildings (I walked to to the JFK park after dinner). The park was filled with people snapping photos but still a beautiful shot to take.

What I found remarkable was the museum that can be seen in the background. Makes a gorgeous view.

What you see is what you get with this sculpture. I was disappointed there was no further explanation of the history of the monument. However, it is to your interpretation whether to experience this art as part of the heart of the city... the City of Brotherly love. At this particular time, a radio station was providing music for a crowd. Unfortunately, I was unable to stay for the live orchestra and fireworks later that evening.
Local here... nice little romantic park only downfall are the homeless and kids that hangout here. But they do leave you alone.

If you feel you must go there, go and take your photo of the LOVE sculpture and the fountain and then beat it out of there. The homeless can get quite aggressive there and often take up all of the benches and the surrounding low wall that goes around the one side of the park. There are lots of skateboarders at the park who will run you over. Litter is everywhere since the natives are too lazy to put their trash in the numerous trash cans around the park, preferring to just chuck their trash on the ground. The one time of the year when it is a nice place to go is between Thanksgiving and Christmas when the entire park hosts a huge Christmas Market (well, actually, the court has forced the city to say a "holiday market") similar to those in Europe. Many of the vendors at that time are from Germany. You could just go to Bethlehem, PA, which is about a 90 minute drive north from Center City Philadelphia and visit probably the best Christkandlemart in the state. Cleaner and safer in Bethlehem, PA.

Cesspool. Homeless people everywhere. Skateboarders everywhere who run you over and fling their urine soaked boards at innocent bystanders. It smells like feces, urine and weed. Only stop by in the daylight, hold your belongings tight and don't stay for more than 5 minutes. If you have a kid who is headed down the wrong path in life, this would be a good place to bring them and scare them straight.
The sign was a lot smaller than I thought it would be. The park is full of homeless people and I really think it is only good to pose for a picture.

It is a good place to spend an hour if you just want to relax on a nice day. The park is clean and it has a cool fountain and a little statue. It is a great place for photo opps! There are some food stands if you are hungry or thirsty. The day I went, there was a live band playing at the park around lunch time.

One suggestion: Restrooms would be a good idea.

Great views from here and a must see photo opportunity.

It looked great on a sunny day with the fountains.

Nothing special about the statue that is,was expecting something much bigger like the one in NY,but it' really small.The park is really nice though surround by the justice court building and so on with beautiful architecture. Again,nothing special unless you're in love than you'll probably love it ;)

On a day trip to Philadelphia my wife wanted to see the love sign. It's nothing special but the view down Benjamin Franklin Parkway towards the museum is nice. Walked around the fountain, took some pictures.

the water from the fountain was blue. the love sign is not perfect, as love is.
the bad part that there were a lot of homeless people.

The iconic symbol of LOVE in the city of brotherly love is a great picture spot and one to create nice memories with your significant other. The sculpture and fountain and view down the parkway towards the Art Museum are very nice, however, with all the transients hanging around the park, it wasn't very tourist friendly.

Honestly, great iconic symbol ... Very beautiful. However, to take your picture there was a line? Yup a line. So instead, I took pictures of the locals. I have a great picture of a kid skateboarding around the fountain. Honestly I was more impressed by the skateboarders. They didn't seem to mind my picture taking. Also the homeless and the skateboarders bring this park to life. That's what makes Philadelphia so interesting!

This was billed as a Christmas Village with vendors of everything Xmas. There were a few very nice booths that had Xmas items but most appeared to be flea market people with scarves, hats and stuff that could be sold anywhere. There was one large tent of all kinds of decorations and German traditional items. Hardly worth the effort to get there though. The park is small and has a Xmas tree but the shopping is sparse and rather disappointing. Food is the same you see everywhere and only a few food vendors with no place to sit inside to enjoy. More of a grab and go place. If you are in the area it is worth a short stop but not worth the travel to it.

Love Park might give people the wrong idea; this is not a park with trees, grass, etc but instead a plaza that offers an introduction to the Benjamin Franklin Parkway. If you want a park, this is not the place for you as it really a plaza, square, whatever you want to call it. It provides an all around view of the urban planning that went into the creation of the Parkway, which extends to its finally at the Art Museum. In short, this should be a quick stop to get a feel to the architecture and setup of Philadelphia as it transitions from center city to the museum district.
Leave a little more time during December to stop at the Christmas Village vendors.

Time for the holidays, the Love Park fountain is replaced by a Christmas Tree!
Went Saturday late morning and felt completely safe, plenty of people around looking at the Holiday Market. If your looking for unique holiday items, this is the place to go.

I imagine the rest of the year round Love Park is worth a quick photo stop in front of the (small) LOVE sculpture and not much else. But for the month of December, there is a "Christmas Village" set up in the square and this makes it a great place to wander for a while, whether day or night, and also makes it much more family friendly.
There is a stage with various musical acts, and temporary shops set up selling all kinds of food - from christmas gifts and decorations to hot drinks, desserts, schnitzels and even bacon jam.
If you're in Philly in the next month, definitely plan to stop by!

Maybe I expected too much, but in essence this is a cute piece of public art on a plinth that you can stand under.

I didn't see or experience any of the issues that other reviewers have mentioned; during my brief visit Sheds had been set up for the Holiday Market, and there were hardly any people around.

Love Park makes for a great photo opportunity, but that's about it.

I wanted to stop here on the hop on hop off tour. Was really surprised how scary this park was. It reeked of urine. Tons of homeless people always pestering for money or food. I was really disappointed that these were the conditions of the area. I wouldn't return again and not with my kids if I ever did go back
Extremely small. Very unsafe. Homelessness everywhere. Almost got hit twice by skateboarders. Very seedy even in daylight.

This is an iconic symbol in Philadelphia. It's not very big, artistic or exciting; but any visitor to Center City, Logan Square or surrounding attractions is nearby anyway, or you probably have to pass it - Why not stop by? The best thing about it is the view you get through the base, framing the Museum of Art at the other end of Benjamin Franklin Parkway (As long as the fountain isn't working).

I did not realize that it is really a small sculpture on a pedestal. It is located in a part that is frequented by a mix of people. I was there on a weekend and it was full of life. Wedding parities were having formal pictures taken under it while homeless people sat around and skateboarders kept flowing by. Yes, it is not a 100% pretty place, but go there to do some people watching. If you are in the neighborhood and walking around, then check it out. It is not recommended to go there at night.

Took the family on an evening walk to Love Park, which was very nice. Please seemed clean - although it was night, area was well-lit, but smelled marijuana being smoked in the area - guess it's bound to happen. the LOVE sign is cool to get pics of. the city hall that's nearby is awesome to look at - the architecture is -- wow

I've always seen it in movies so it was on my "things to do" in Philly. Found it fine, a lil crazy to get to. It's really a few snaps for pics and done. I told my family to stay in car cause there's no parking anywhere near there. I jumped out of car on the corner took 6 pics and hopped back in. It was cold and snow was all over so nothing else to see but thought there was a gift shop but never made it to there. Good stop and free to see LOVE. ❤️

That's about it. Go there, see the LOVE sign, snap a few shots, move on. There's not much else to see except the people seeing if they can take a photo of you - for some money of course.
It does make a nice photo spot though.
We went to Love Park because of the Christmas Market. It was nice, lots of vendors. It was a good 30 minutes to 45 minutes fun. We also took some photo with the LOVE statue.

As a complete newbie to Philly, my friend took me to the Christmas Village in Love Park. The center of the park was decorated with a tall, brilliantly lit Christmas Tree. There were booths selling traditional German fare, mulled cider, chocolates, trinkets and jewelry. The cider was tasty and quickly warmed me up. I purchased a great necklace from one of the larger jewelry vendors. There was a line of kissing couples waiting to take their picture under the love sculpture. The atmosphere was inviting and spirited. There is no enterance fee. Unfortunately the village closes down around 7pm, which was a bit early for us.

Most of the year, Love Park is great for about five minutes. You can admire the big sign and the fountain, then you can admire the view up the Ben Franklin Parkway toward the Art Museum.

Here ends your tour of Love Park. It's a great five minutes, but don't spend much more. Head up the Ben Franklin Parkway to see Philadelphia's many fine museums.

The only exception is the holidays, when the Christmas Village moves in, then you should make some more time. Make sure to get a pretzel or some strudel, they're excellent! Check out the various small shops, and enjoy the live music that is often playing in the park this time of year.
Nothing really special, just a place you can take photo with the "LOVE" landmark. There is Market right now, but nothing really special that you can't buy from the mall.

Nothing special, just a place to take photos. Came here on Christmas eve so there was a Christmas Village around it. However, the items being sold were commonly found in shopping malls. Be wary of people trying to make extra bucks from you by offering their help in taking photos for you.

Family and I drove over from New Jersey to check out the German Christmas village. Although Love Park is small, the Christmas village features numerous vendors offering home made gifts including ornaments, hand made clothing and much more. We enjoy the festive atmosphere of the park this time of year, and would recommend to anybody looking to kill an hour or so in a festive environment! Always nice to take photos by the Love Park sculpture or the beautiful Christmas tree on display!
So it's just a fountain... but actually it's quite iconic. ppl can gather around taking pictures, relaxing..

Being born in Europe and living there for a few years I have experienced the authentic Christmas villages. The Christmas Village at Love Park was pretty close to being authentic, minus the location of the village. Love Park itself is not too big, so it was a little crammed with all the vendor booths at the village but was still pretty fun.

They had a German sausages and Gluwine (hot wine) which hit the spot. Also had a booth with authentic german candies, chocolate and more. Cool place to visit for an hour if your in the city.

Other than the love sculpture there was not much more to see here. The park is a bit dirty, with trash and skateboarders all around. There was a man taking photos for tips at the statue...which with a long line up helped to expedite the tourists and they all got a nice pic together. He was kind and never asked for money but tips are appreciated. He took good pics give him a tip! This is also stop 6 on the big bus tour and other bus companies stop here too.
I thought the sculpture was bigger. Love Park is okay for a quick stop for photos. Best thing is the view of Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

We stopped here enroute to the Barnes Foundation to take a photo. I always thought the LOVE statue was larger. With the fountain as a backdrop it does make for a nice photo opportunity and it is close to city hall and the Reading a Terminal market.

I'm not sure why this is on the list of attractions for Philadelphia. There are occasional events there, but generally it's a small, unimaginative, uneventful park. If you work in the area and the weather is perfect, go sit and eat lunch there and people watch.

The Love sculpture is much smaller than we had thought. But the live Jazz was absolutely worth half an hour and a mellow sit down. Food trucks were there. One had a HUGE queue - clearly great food. But we cant keep up with all the goodies on offer to eat.

There's a lot to see around the area, but the Love Park itself will probably cost you only 20 minutes of your day. I came here on a rainy day, so there wasn't much of a crowd, but I can imagine it being pretty busy during tourist season - plan to wait in line to take a photo under the "Love" structure.

Go early in the day, on a weekday if you can, to take a photo under the LOVE sign. The sign gets very crowded in the afternoon/evening and hustlers try to take your money if you want a photo with the statue.

Taking pic below the LOVE sign is very teenager-ish... and I am way past that age... so that did not attract me... the sign looks rather small and unimpressive in person.. But the park is pretty even without the fountain running (it was early spring).
It probably is a lot better with the fountain going in the warmer months, but that didn't stop us from taking pictures. Best time to go is in the morning so the sun is behind you.

Well, took my wife to Philly for our Anniversary and we finally made it over to Love Park. Unfortunately, our Anniversary is in Winter so attractions like a park aren't at their peak attractiveness. It was fun, but we were immediately confronted by several people wanting to snap pictures for you, for a tip of course, but it makes you a little nervous to hand over your expensive camera to a complete stranger. It all worked out well though and we got some great photos.
This place was a little park where u can take pics infront of the philly LOVE sign or take a splash in the fountain.. Its a must visit park if in Philly

Not sure why this is getting great reviews. We didn't even stop to go into the park. It looked like lots of homeless people and the love sculpture is not near as big as it looks in photos. Also very busy traffic area around there. So we just snapped a photo as we drove by.

Definitely worth a quick stop for some great pictures! The surrounding area is lovely too... City Hall across the street and all the super scaled "toy" playing pieces on the other square across the street are so fun.
It was on my "must visit" list, but it wasn't overly impressive. It appears to have been neglected and overrun by skateboarders.
This park never disappoints. It's just so relaxing, and you're likely to find hidden treasures, like artists showcasing their work. I went home with a terrific original painting!

Cool LOVE statue, but it's much smaller in person than I'd expected. Not the nicest side of town, and mostly young kids and homeless ppl in the vicinity. Luckily a policeman on a segue was on patrol. Huge fountain was spraying which mad it difficult to get a dry picture, but all in all it was worth the experience.
If you expect to see a park, there is none. Fountain in the middle of downtown which could be rescuing on the hot afternoons. Hold on to your purse and plan to see some more around.

LOVE statue is much smaller that I expected. There is a water feature there to observe. Some garden planters with varying flora. Other than that...not much else. Worth a walk by on your way to something else, but not a destination.
Great to sit and watch the water for a team meeting or just a break in the day!!! The sculpture is a lot smaller in person and the people watching and fountain are much more intriguing.
One of pleasant places to go and visit in CC Philadelphia. would definetely return there. It is a nice place for a stroll or place to relax, and lets not forget a pic by the LOVE sign.

LOVE Park (JFK Plaza) is very iconic for Robert Indiana's art installation. The actual installation is smaller than I had envisioned. It's a great spot for taking pictures. The park is very lively and is utilized by all sorts of people; office workers, skate-boarders, tourists, etc. However, the actual park space is not that big. Even though it's a popular landmark, I don't think it's comparable to the Bean in Chicago in terms of size and space. For me, the park provided a nice recess from exploring the city all day. There was a street performer playing music while I was there. Overall, it's a convenient stop along the way to CIty Hall and Reading Terminal Market.
Very iconic of Philadelphia. However, the actual statue is surprisingly small. Good for a photo, but other than that, it's nothing spectacular.

The sculpture was a bit of disappointment.I thought it would be bigger. I liked the huge fountain behind the sculpture more.

The park itself had lots of people sitting around and in the fountain. Some guys where skateboarding in the park as well.

The vibrancy of the crowds is a big draw for visitors to Love Park. The intriguing LOVE sculpture coupled with the fountain shooting water high into the air ensure a lively surrounding for everyone. There is a delightful variety of people who make up the crowd here so it is not a place to relax. Instead, choose this place to celebrate the joyful rhythms of life. A selfie in front of the sculpture is a must.

Good place, but disliked the old Black Lady who thinks she owns the place and expects to be tipped by EVERYONE who so much as goes within 20 feet of the water fountain. Just ignore her and you will be fine !! ( Not Fined ;-)) )
A quick view while walking through is definitely a stress reliever. Water Fountains definitely make you feel better and the way LOVE is displayed definitely brings upon a smile.

It's not a bad place to visit when you are around downtown seeing other places but on its own, it really doesn't offer much. Just drop in, take a pic in front of the LOVE sculpture and move on to your next destination. The fountain was moderately clean and the people around seemed harmless enough.
I was expecting more. Fountain was clean which based on other reviews, I got lucky. There was a lot to do around the park but was somewhat disappointed with the park itself.
It's a busy park with homeless people and children playing in a dirty fountain?! I really do not see what all the hype is about... Just my opinion!
You can see many things around the park, that are very interesting, but the park doesn't offer much to see besides the sculpture.

It was very relaxing by the water fountain and the landscaping. We didn't see any homeless people when we went. The statue was a bit smaller than I anticipated, but it was great seeing an iconic landmark. On the first day we were the the water was green, then after that it was normal color. We're not sure what the significance of the colored water was, but it was pretty. Good place for a photo op.

We went here after a stop at the Rocky statue where we were basically harassed by some homeless dude to let him take our picture. He wouldn't let us say no, so we caved. Anyways, the Philly Phlash dropped us off here and we were surprised to find the same homeless dude here! (I guess they move around frequently). This time, we told him we didn't have anything else to give him. He told his wife, "Tweety Bird," that we already gave them something so she could take our picture for no cost (how generous). The statue itself was smaller than I expected, but a great photo op. There was a nice fountain behind it. Tweety Bird took great pictures, but I'm still really annoyed that they were so persistent. I feel like it's a common problem in Philly and that the police should really do something about it so the tourists feel safer. So, go get a picture here, but only take $1. (When we rode past this the next day, the same homeless people were there hitting up tourists)
This park is nice to see during the day, especially to see the famous Love statue. I would not go there at night though.
don't go there after dark, many homeless people hang out there at nigh and I don't know if they're dangerous or not but sure scary.

Just as a heads up, make sure you ask another tourist to take your photo while here. There are plenty of very engaging people who will offer to take your photo for you....then want a "donation" of a dollar or two for helping. It is relatively small, and there's nothing really else in the park.
cute little park (jfk park) located near city hall (which is gorgeous!) . the love statue is surprisingly small . very under-whelming

The size of the LOVE sculpture was not as big as I envisioned it to be. A park good for pictures - Other than if you are lucky and have enough time, there's music and other art/culture performances at noon.

The Love sculpture was "iconic," but lacked anything else. Lots of homeless people at the fountain "park" and bothering everyone to give money... If passing by stop, but other wise you are not missing anything special.

This park was simply beautiful. On the day we visited, the water was blue. The Philadelphia park association was having a dance in the park, people were listening to music mixed by a DJ. While another parks person was leading everyone. At first they were doing a hustle, then they switched to a step. The main reason we were there was to take pictures at the Love sculpture. This was a great place to be. The blue water shooting up in the air from the fountain was visable from the famous "Rocky Steps" at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
I wasn't sure what to expect when I went to see this--figured it would be bigger. Nope it was kinda small and a bit disappointing

We stopped here (was one of the stops on a tour we were taking) mainly to take our picture by the LOVE sign. There are folks walking around offering to take your picture; however, we just asked the people behind us to take our picture and we took a few for them. Go earlier in the day because the sun moves and the sign loses some natural sun light. The one thing I thought was nice is that a line forms so when it is your turn, no one else is in your picture. We didn't spend too much time here but look around as the architecture of the surrounding buildings is beautiful.

There is usually a person there offering to take your picture at the LOVE statue with your camera for you. As a couple it was great to have someone offer to do that instead of having to ask someone. All you have to do is tip them $1. It is worth the buck, because they will take 3-4 pictures of you telling you to do different poses, the pictures are funny. Just do it, don't be cheap. Its a buck & they are so nice.

The park is a close walk to the liberty bell/Independence Hall.

We stumbled upon this park while walking around downtown and its a cute little area that they have cleaned up with a gorgeous fountain perfect for pictures. The small LOVE statue is the main attraction as a line was formed to take pictures so allow for a few minutes if you would like one. Beautiful downtown buildings and architectures surround the park.

I was passing through the area and unintentionally saw this park. A huge pink water fountain and the much smaller LOVE statue was the attraction. I personally like water to be clear, like nature intended. The floor tiles were shaky to walk on.

It was nice to see it, but it was not inviting enough for me to stop. Average at best. I would only recommend it if you want to take a picture of the statue.
Basically just a place to take photos and relax. Cute park near City Hall, the fountain is beautiful when it's on. Don't be surprised if you see homeless people penny pinching in the water.

Nice little park tucked away in downtown Philly. It makes for a great photo op. Nice fountain and skyline backdrop. Great mix of people and enjoyed having some food trucks nearby. The view from the park down Benjamin Franking Parkway to the Museum of Art is spectacular with all the green trees.

there is nothing to see! the "LOVE" sculpture is really small!
At the park you gonna meet a lot of homeless people... :( it's not a fun place to stay)!

If you are planning to walk around can be a stop for 10 min at least!
If visiting Philly, you have to see it. Go during the day and beware of the scammers & crazies. Occasionally there are radical protestors, just use common sense & watch surroundings.

Haha...small park downtown Philly that I have wanted to get to since I first saw a photograph of the LOVE sculpture! Water fountain, skateboarders, food trucks, too! When if Philladelphia, get here & take a pic, then head down to Reading Terminal Market & get your eat on~ yum. That review is next. :)

It's true there isn't a lot to do here other than sit by the fountain or have your photo taken by the 'Love' statue but sometimes that's enough! At the end of a long day sightseeing it was a place to go to reflect, feel the cool spray from the fountain and watch the world go by. There are some characters there but I never felt threatened, even on an evening when a peaceful demonstration was scheduled with police presence. I will always remember it as the place my son wanted to go to whilst we had 3 days together before the start of his year at Temple. Happy times!

I love the city of Philadelphia and have been there many times and seen a lot of the sites, but I don't get Love Park. I've passed by it on the way to other sites, restaurants and just ran by it during the marathon. It's a small park in the center of downtown with the Love statue in it. I get the statue is iconic, but that's it. There's nothing else to see there and as some of the other reviewers have mentioned there's a lot of homeless people that hang around the park.

IT is amazing to sit down and watch the skaters practiceing all kind of diffrent jumps on their skateboards.The park has perfect ground for doing skateboard moves, we sat there for one hour just watching....
We walked here and it was nice to see. I took a quick picture and got the heck out of there! Too many bums/homeless, it is sad to see and the smells are overwhelming!
Seriously, no other spot is as famous than the LOVE statue. Walking distance from City Center, great spot for a selfie or a group photo and en route to the Rocky Statue

When we went to Philly I had to see the LOVE statue and fountain. Once there, I questioned my decision to bring my kids. Plenty of tourists but also a lot of homeless people, obnoxious teenagers with foul mouths, and people dressed up trying to get tips for taking your picture. One guy was dressed as Jesus and getting paid to have his picture taken with tourists. I'm glad I can say I saw it, but I certainly wouldn't go again with kids.

The photo linked to this attraction is the one commonly seen when watching sporting event, or any advertisement for Philadelphia. However, in reality, it is nothing more than a homeless camp. People sleeping on benches, aimlessly walking around asking for change, or mumbling to themselves. Treat yourself to a walk through the park and count how many objectionable odors you can detect throughout. There will be some that you never new existed.

This park is overrated and should be an embarrassment to the city. It is filthy and a place I would certainly not recommend, especially at night.
This was a beautiful spot to enjoy and take pictures, but I was very disappointed in the actual size of the sculpture. Pictures lead us to believe that the "Love" was much larger than it actually is.

A wonderful and peaceful place in busy place. Nice fountain, Love art work and pleasant place to sit and jut relax. nice breeze with moisture which can drench you completely what else you want when you are with your loved one

Love Park is more of an intimate spot where people can sit, lay down, relax, and admire the sights and sounds of the water fountain. I was able to sit down and relax and enjoy the breeze omitting from the fountain, plus it was such a beautiful day outside. I admire fountains and admire them even more if they are sophisticated. Love Park is a place to be to hang out for a while and relax.
This is a great place for fun photos and sight seeing...and with the fountain pink for breast cancer awareness month...it was even better!!!

In its Kristkindtmarkt incarnation for the holidays, Love Park sparkles, especially at night. This is a stop that should be included during your Philly Christmas tour. Make sure you catch the Macy's light show in the old Wanamaker building, meeting friends under the eagle.

Since it was chilly, we grabbed some coffees from the local shops and took in the atmosphere of the center of city hall, bustling with workers leaving for the subways and trains. But in the outdoor atrium, there was holiday music and a tree from Delaware County all decked out in its Christmas gear. The modern tables and chairs along with the magnificent architecture hinted of sidewalk cafés in Paris. We were in the middle of an island of calm.

Then take in the top of city hall, 22 stories high, under the blessing hand of the 32 foot tall, 54,000 thousand pound statue of William Penn. The trip is times, limited to four persons due to the tiny elevator and costs between $4-8, depending on your age. The ride up, seeing the innards of the building was worth the price of admission. Fantastic girders and stonework, and views could be caught through the glass walled elevator. Children and seniors get a discount. We caught the skyline just at dusk, and Philadelphia looked magnificent. All of us, residents of this region for decades were so proud of our city.

Then, back to Love Park for a bite to eat. We strolled past the newly installed ice skating rink and watched families having fun. The redesigned plaza is so much more inviting and friendly than the old one, with landscaping, and seating, and a little bistro. But onto the Christmas market. Yes, the food is overpriced, but authentic. My favorite is lebercase (hot bologna on a bed of potato salad) and the bratwurst. You definitely get the feel of being in the German festive atmosphere. Then we strolled through the shops, and stopped by Kathie Wohlfarht for our annual fix of genuine German crafts. Yes, it is all overpriced, but having been at the original store inGermany, it was over priced there as well. I did some shopping and thought it is a lot less expensive than a round trip flight to Germany.

We all left with a genuine appreciation for the city space from above and on the ground. This place is good for all ages, if you want to catch a whiff of something special!

Parking is underground under Love Park. $14 to park. The Christmas market was free though. Not what I expected at all. Overpriced German (WAY overpriced) but beautiful to look at. We had the grilled cheese sticks and the chicken kabobs. They were both fabulous. The market though was a complete disappointment. Sad. So we headed to Bethlehem's Christmas Market.

I was going to stop at Love Park for a picture so that I could send it home, but my visit ended up being so much more. During the winter they have a German Christmas theme set up with a bunch of little vendors in make shift stores. There were a lot of hand made items and my favorite…German food. Pretzels and other treats which are very difficult to replicate authentic were available. I had planned on only stopping for a short time, but spent almost an hour in that small block. The city did an excellent job of organizing a great event.

My adult daughter and I went to Love Park while the German Xmas Market was in full swing. Love Park itself is not worth going out of your way unless you happen to be in the area. However, the Xmas market was really good. Good spiced wine, different foods, and an impressive variety of decorations and wooden displays imported from Germany.

Visited the Christmas Village. Unfortunately it was raining so we didn't really get to appreciate it. Love the German theme. Lots of shopping. Wish I could have stayed out in the rain longer, but my feet were soaked. Loved the large tent with all the Christmas ornaments! Lots of fun. Didn't eat any food however it smelled amazing!!!

I highly recommend spending some time and money at the market if you are visiting during the holiday season. German goods as well as something for everyone. They also had a live band and plenty of good food and drink choices.

Visited the Christmas Village and the food and drinks were great!!! From Belgium waffles to churros, everything was tasty. Lots of hand made items that were interesting. Went to the German ornament store and they are way overpriced. The Love sign was tiny though. I've been to Philly now several times since I'm close by and this was only one of two where my fiancee and I were harassed by either homeless or those homeless that were trying to sell something. One guy yelled at me from far away to come and buy something and I ignored it. However, the guy who harassed my fiancee by catcalling got an earful when I went up to his face and told him to shut up and get some teeth (he was missing a lot of teeth). Homeless don't bother me, but they're an issue when they harass others for no reason. Police were there, but were ignoring the homeless completely. Overall, it's nice to visit the city, but you have to be aware of your surroundings.

The Love sign was a little smaller than I thought it would be (isn't everything ha ha?) but still a great photo-op and nice to visit. We loved shopping at the "Christmas Village" and got some decent deals & fun food & beverages. We also had fun across the street taking pictures with the giant board game pieces (Sorry markers, Monopoly pieces, dominoes, etc.).

Since the Christmas village was there we spent a couple of hours walking around, shopping, taking pictures, etc. but I'm not sure if you'd need that much time if the village wasn't there (it's seasonal only). It's worth stopping to see if you have the time.

Apparently I got the Philly sign mixed up with the one in NYC b/c it's about 1/3 of the size :-/ But it's nice because you can stand under it rather than next to it. Note: "self employed" photographers will offer to take your pic on your cell...and then ask for a tip after. I can't knock the hustle, I was fine giving a couple bucks because she actually got some good angles!

We went during the Christmas Market on Saturday. A bit congested, we were in and out!

This wasn't quite the green park I envisioned, but it was still neat to see such an iconic site. We stopped here to take a few pictures on our way to the historic center, which is about all the time it takes to see. Unfortunately the fountains were turned off on the day we visited, and they would have probably added some more charisma to the scene. It's nice to see, and won't take too long. Worth a quick stop.
The love park is cute and fun to take pictures at, and when the weather is nice it's fun to walk around and be touristy.
Beautiful, fun event for Christmas shopping. There was a choir singing and lots of vendors selling anything you can think of! It's a short walk to the Comcast Center to see the light show.

We came upon this by accident, but we were so happy we did! We got last minute ornaments and gifts and some things for ourselves we couldn't resist! Santa was there one day, and Jesus was there the next. See the fans who show up?? If we could have stayed for another day, we would have returned again; it was that much fun!

I had brought my wife who is from Ohio downtown to see the lights so we stopped at love Park for the Christmas village it was a bunch of shops ( sheds) selling homemade jewelry that was very poorly made and little crafts I would not go out of my way again to see it again

Have been a few times. Most recently for a Christmas craft fair. If you're not from the city, it's neat to look at. The Love Statute is kind of an icon for Philly, so grab a photo and then check out City Hall or whatever.

I had lived in Munich for about 3 years before moving to Philadelphia and I was greeted with this market a week after I made the shift. It has a total German feel about it (including German sweets, drinks and food) and there is the America spirit rolled in.! Awesome place to spend an afternoon.. :)
One of my favorite places to be in Philly. I absolutely love the statue, and the fountain is beautiful. It is in the heart of the city and just refreshing.

Christmas Village is something you should see at least once. This was my second time there as I took an out of town guest. The parking lot below is difficult to find if you are coming the wrong way on the street. However $14 is not so bad to park since the Village entrance is free (you have to go to the information booth to get the $14 price). Be sure to dress warm as it is very cold walking for an hour or two most of it outdoors - hat, gloves, etc. are in order. Items are very high priced so be prepared for this if you want to make a purchase. My gripe is the "park" area that the Village is on. It has always bothered my that the marble stone that you walk on are not secure and loose and as you walk they shift. Also look forward when you walk as the area has constant ledges and steps. I have to believe in all of these years that there have been accidents with falls at this event. Another thing I noticed was that there was no police presence in the Village. Suburban events almost always have assigned police officers which is something they should talk to the police department about. If there were any assigned inside the Village they were not seen by myself or guest who were there for about 90 minutes.

Explored Christmas Village set up at Love Park in Philadelphia today. It was a fun holiday event to enjoy. Lots to lovely craft type things to look at. A stop at the wandering waffle that was covered in strawberries and served with chocolate dipping sauce. Worth at least a look.
I don't see what you would do here without the Christmas fair. It's just a large concrete area. The Christmas fair was nice though.

I have seen far too many reviews on here about it being a let down or not what you expect... Please realize that you are going to see a sign that says LOVE in the middle of a park. THAT IS IT! It is exactly as advertised and you will get no more and no less!

I think it is a must see. Classic photo op for the city of brotherly love. It is close to many other attractions and it doesn't take long.

FYI.. There was a woman there offering to take pictures for your group.. It is not required and she not work there. She just asks for tips. We took her up on her offer and she was fun. She took a couple of pictures of us with fun poses and she was kind.

What more do you need?

Great must do experience in Philly. Looks down towards the iconic Philadelphia Museum of Art, beautiful walk from LOVE to all that art along the way.

I stop and take a photo every time I'm in town. No photo is ever the same.

We stopped by because we were in the area and figured it would be a good opportunity to take pictures. We still took pictures, but I had a very disappointed friend who uttered the sentence, "This can't be it." It is much smaller than what we had in mind, which is our own fault of course. However, I would not go out of your way to stop by.

Nice little park with a good theme for popping "the question" and taking pictures! She said yes so of course I'd give this place 5 stars! Not too far of the path of things to see. We had a nice time in Philly!
Not a lot to do here during the winter, but the "Love" sign is a great photo spot. The sign was smaller than we had anticipated, but we had no other issues here.

If you are ever in the city, this is a great place for a picture. There is a parking garage right below the park. Afterwards, take a walk to the Liberty Bell. However, take the Philadelphia Phlash Transit Loop bus back to get dropped off right in front of Love Park.

This place is a toliet. All the homeless use it as a restroom, the skaters have torn the steps all up, and then there are the rats. The sign is small and not worth your time. I'm embarrassed that tourists come to this city and see this, I'm downright disgusted with how the city keeps it.

My Husband and I were strolling around Philadelphia streets on a Saturday Evening. We had heard so much about this park, and were not disappointed. The night was chilly, so there were hardly 7-8 folks around the park. It was a beautiful place. The art was much smaller than what we could see on photographs. A passerby offered to click a photograph for us.
Glad we stopped here. We got the perfect picture. It is really pretty with the water fountain behind it.

Glad we stopped here. The cool statue with the water fountain behind it seemed to be a popular attraction, several homeless people hanging around anxious to snap a pic for tourists for a small fee. :)

There is a fountain behind the "love" that got us really wet while taking the picture! I didn't really explore around the park cause I was only focusing on taking that picture. Nearby, there are some big pieces of games like chess. It's cool to see.

We went on a sunny Saturday, and had the same experience reported by other TA users of homeless people taking your picture for "tips." The two there were arguing with each other about the system for who got which tourists, which was a nightmare, and they had taken it upon themselves to organize who got to go up to the sign and when. If you don't mind ignoring them and refusing their offer for their "services," take your quick pictures and move on. The rest of the park is pretty neat as well.

We went to get our photo in front of the love statue. It was a nice day so it was pretty crowded. We waited in line for a few minutes while 2 guys were taking people's pictures for 'tips'. This is not required! We took our own picture for free. So just be aware. Wouldn't want to be around this area after dark.
