It's superbly located, and you can take fun pictures (beware of opportunists that ask you if you want them to take your picture and then ask for money!). Other than this, take a break from your tour and eat a sub with both feet in the water :)

I have memories of seeing this piece of art reproduced on T shirts for the last 30yrs. I was excited to see the original piece of art in a public space in Philly.
This city is amazing with public art spaces around every corner.
The big tick of approval from me.

Cute and iconic sculpture in Philadelphia.

Be aware of local hustlers offering to take your picture then demanding money.

We stumbled on this small park, which has the official name of John F. Kennedy Plaza, when walking to the nearby City Hall. The space earned the nickname "Love Park" after a sculpture by Robert Indiana was installed here for the 1976 bicentennial. This sculpture displays red letters LO over VE on a pedestal. It seemed to be a small insignificant work to me, so I became curious about why visitors had formed a short line to photograph it.

I learned later that the sculpture is a favorite photo op in the city with the park's fountain and city buildings in the background and is connected with skateboarding history.The curved granite steps leading down to the fountain attracted skateboarders from around the world in the past and was featured in various magazines and films. But skateboarding has been banned here for years.

Those interested in Philadelphia's more recent history and a photo op may find this to be a worthwhile place to stop. A city welcome center stands at one end of the plaza.

Brilliant photo spot and a nice play to chill on a hot sunny day. The fountain offers refreshing breeze which is nice on a hot day in a city. There are lots of gorgeous blooming trees which make the place look even more special in the spring.

Very small, but the LOVE spot is definitely a great photo stop. On a sunny and warm day, it is nice to have the fountain water spraying. Great people watching place too. Be sure to walk 360, to get multiple photo angles: one to the City Hall, and the other down the route all the way to the Philadelphia Art Museum steps.

This was not a let down, it was exactly what we read about, seen images of. You get exactly what this was described to us. Make it part of your wonder walk in Philadelphia! People always smile when they pose under the LOVE statue.

In the mid-1980's a group of young people discovered Vincent Kling's curving steps and ledges to be perfect for skateboarding. It was the combination of the different levels and curves, continuous granite surfaces, and the large space for sessions that attracted skaters. Gradually LOVE Park's reputation spread around the skateboard community as skateboarders from all over the city and surrounding suburbs flocked to LOVE Park. Its close proximity to all major subway and regional rail lines made LOVE so easily accessible to all. All of these factors led LOVE Park to become an icon for the city's youth community. In the early 1990's, with the rising appeal of urban street skating, many of the world's most talented, professional skateboarders decided to make LOVE Park their training grounds. The space quickly became known internationally as one of the finest skate parks in the world and later the “World Capitol of Skateboarding.” Tourists came from all over the world to see and skate the famous skate spot. LOVE Park in this period was featured in every major skateboarding/action sports magazine and was showcased in films by all of the major players of the industry. There is even a popular video game featuring skateboard LOVE Park. In 2000 and 2001, LOVE Park's vast fame brought ESPN's X-Games to Philadelphia. The X-Games brought millions of dollars in tourism and was watched by 150 million households worldwide. Its events and publicity all focused around Philadelphia's skateboard scene, LOVE Park in particular. LOVE's international reputation as an ideal skateboarding locale has been strengthened by the successes of some its most famous users. Internationally known professional skateboarders like Ricky Oyola, Josh Kalis, Stevie Williams, and Anthony Pappalardo made their names in the multibillion-dollar skateboarding industry by being identified with their frequent use of LOVE's famous ledges and stair sets.
While it is now illegal to skate there, many still do. If you get a chance go there and see it! It is history!

I thought it was strange that so many people were wading in the fountain, clothes and all. Not just little kids but adults of all ages. There were also lots of bums sleeping all over the park. Overall and interesting atmosphere.

You cannot miss the colorful LOVE sculptor .
( oh if you need to see more that one LOVE in situ, venture to the U of Pennsylvania in west Philly). Park is elevated on JFK blvd. just NW of City Hall. Visitor center. Music at times.

I sat in this nice little park near City Hall. The water fountain is inviting and some kids were playing in the water although there is a sign that says no swimming. Nice photo opportunity at the park sign that say LOVE on it but beware of individuals hanging around offering to take your picture of you for you. They want a hand-out for doing so.

Make sure to visit one of Philadelphia’s many fountains to cool off on a hot day. Whether you just want to dip your feet in or spend the whole day, the fountains are a great place to go. The fountain in LOVE Park is a great opportunity for some pictures as well! When we went we even saw a group of people doing tricks on skateboards. Although the fountains themselves are very pretty, the surrounding parks are a bit dirty and there are a lot of homeless people living in them. However, don’t let that deter you from visiting because Philadelphia’s fountains are definitely worth seeing!

Took a wonderful stroll and was surprised by the huge LOVE artwork, and looking down one of the main streets, all the flags. Nice sightseeing! There was even a homeless man who noticed me snapping pictures and jumped in front of me and begged, "Take a picture of me!" with a big, toothless smile :) Was happy to have made his day !

There were several local people there that were kind of directing the line of people trying to take pictures and asking for tips in exchange. They were also offering to take pictures for us which was convenient but they were kind of annoying because they wouldn't just let you take your picture when you were ready you kind of felt forced into waiting even if you were in a hurry.
Small little park, but that sign is outstanding, just love it. Hubby and i have a great pic taken by it. I will post it!

Just stop and take the iconic picture! It's not much of a "park" and there are quite a few homeless in the area but I never felt unsafe. In fact a few have decided to make a living by being a "photographer" for the LOVE statue and will take a family picture. Our photographer George was awesome and we tipped him appropriately! Worth the stop for the picture but you might only be here for 5 minutes!

I stopped here early in the morning so I could get some clear shots without the hoards of people. Unfortunately my love was at work, so no pics of us. Nice park, is pretty busy all through out the day of tourists or locals eating lunch or meeting up. The sign was smaller than I thought it would be. Stop take some pics and keep exploring.

Despite “selfie sticks,” obviously homeless men ask for money to take photos of couples standing in front of the famed LOVE Park sign. Ask them for their Social Security numbers, so that you can report that income to the IRS.☺ On a self-guided walking tour, I saw the sign when leaving Masonic Temple. There are a dozen attractions within two blocks of this sign, like Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. It seems, like Rome, all roads lead to this park. The plaza is surrounded by statues and plaques that give a bit of history. View the sign from both sides of the Old Faithful-like fountain. Until Philadelphia imposed a ban in 2002, LOVE Park was the world capital of skateboarding, because of the curved steps. LOVE Park is in the JFK Plaza, at John F. Kennedy Blvd. and North 15th St., northwest of City Hall.
Not exactly a park. A small area near city center and a nice fountain. People usally posing there for a quick picture in front of the LOVE sign

Love Park is one of the most popular Philadelphia landmarks. Of course it is a must-see, most especially if you are in the vicinity of city hall. This is the place to take your loved ones and take your mandatory vacation pictures.

Aside from the iconic LOVE sculpture, the park has a fountain where kids and kids-at-heart can play (fun fact: it is allowed to play in public fountains in Philadelphia, that is according to our tour guide, anyway). And it is located near other Philadelphia landmarks.

Now go and take your quintessential Philadelphia pictures!

So I'm from Texas and when I think of Park I think of green grass, trees, and things to do in the park. This park is in the middle of downtown, the LOVE sign is very small, and the fountain is very big. I wouldn't call it a park, more like a fountain in the middle of downtown. Maybe it's a northern thing??

This is pretty much just a quick photo op. We asked a family behind us to take our picture, and we reciprocated for them. We did not stay long here due to what looked liked homeless people yelling at each other with many curse words.

This park is very close to City Hall so an easy walk to take a quick picture. Its crowded and yes the statue is much smaller than you think it would be. There is a large fountain and lots of "locals" milling about.
This is the iconic "LOVE" statue in the city of brotherly love. It's smaller than you may think, but still nice for a photo op. Definitely worth a visit, even just for a couple minutes.

I must say I was disappointed with the park because of its condition and lack of security. To begin, the love statue is much smaller than I anticipated. There are teenagers skating through the park recklessly without any authority preventing it. Additionally, while forming a line to take a picture of the statue there are homeless people coming up to you trying to take a picture for you using your device for a fee, which is creepy if you are a family with children. Other than this and the fountain, not much else to see.

user_base: Rock Hill, South Carolina, United States
review: The famous symbol from the beautiful movie, Love Story, this iconic statue is the center piece of Love Park.
This is a nice spot for taking pictures. I steer away from this area late at night, for it can get a bit seedy.

That's what she said!

Sorry. I had to.

It is though. I mean, it isn't Mona Lisa small, but the letters are always photographed close up so you don't realize they are rather small and on a raised platform. It was a pretty day when I went, so the view was very nice and colorful with the fountain backdrop.

A couple of things to note for visitors:
-Lots of homeless, vagrants in the area. I have lived in enough cities to just accept this as par for the course, unfortunate as that may sound, but most of the people who appeared to be panhandlers or whatever you want to call them in this area were circling tourists looking to be of service. If this is new to you, they want a tip if you accept their help. I politely declined the rather large gentleman who followed me a few yards asking to take my photo for me. Other tourists seemed to be doing the same.
-Lots of bird poop. Just wear some shoes or thicker flip flops. I tend to be more fastidious than most, but with the amount of bird poop and the mist from the fountain giving everything a dusting of moisture, I wasn't keen on walking all over the immediate area for too long.
-Don't just take one photo of the sculpture! Turn round and round. It is centered in an area with gorgeous buildings. Take advantage of what is in the area.
-Smile! You're at a statue that is about love!

The LOVE sign is a lot smaller than it appears in pictures, but is really a symbol of Philly so I feel you need to see it. There are so many skateboarders and loitering, which makes it hard to get a good picture in front of it!

Any trip to Philadelphia, must include a trip to Love Park, this is a busy yet peaceful stop for any traveller on a warm sunny day!! with great views of the historic buildings around the square. The park def has that romantic feel to it, and is a great place to sit down and chat to many a passer buy!

This adorable little park in the heart of Philadelphia houses one of the iconic "LOVE" statues by Robert Indiana. Park guests line up orderly waiting their turn for a special photo under the sculpture. Tradition seems to be to ask whomever is after you in line to take your photo. The whole experience feels of love. It is a "must experience".

Situated right across the city hall, this is must visit place in philly, houses the famous LOVE symbol, only downside is the fact that during late evening hours, it becomes bit unsafe to roam around, as lot of mischievious/shady characters are around the place..but still photograph with the LOVE symbol and fountain behind is must do...

First thing you'll probably think is that the Love sculpture is really small. It seemed to me like a cheap knock off of the pictures you'd see in books and tv.
The frame of the sculpture I thought was was also rather ugly but what i also found ugly was the people hanging around asking if they could take your picture with your phone and then expect to be paid. This is probably the only time i would be grateful for a selfie stick.
The area immediately around the sculpture seemed unkept, rundown and rather uninviting.
The fountain was impressive but the whole place needs a makeover in my opinion. I spent less than 10 minutes there. Also watch out the subway station entrance adjoining was a collection point for drug addicts and stunk of urine.
Good to say you've seen the sculpture i suppose but don't fret if you cannot fit it in.

I was surprised to see just ow popular this attraction is with visitors. I was there on several occasions in May/June and it was always so busy. Despite its popularity though in my observations there was always a friendly, jovial atmosphere and there was no pushing into the line. It is very well located. Those not wanting to walk to the park can get the 33 or 38 bus from Market St, just down from Hard Rock Cafe.
I wouldn't stop here. You can see the Love art piece from the road on one of the tours. I did walk through the park at night and felt safe.
Loved this quirky park and loved having our photo taken under the LOVE sign - definitely worth a visit.

This is a fun little stop on a walk. The fountain is pretty and everyone lines up to have pictures under the LOVE sculpture. Everyone helps everyone out as far as snapping pictures of families, couples,etc.
The Love Park, small as it is, has beautiful fountains, lawns and public seating under the shadow or lush greens. No lovers (by way of PDA) spotted.
This is a short and must see when in the city. Easily accesible on foot and within walking distance of City Hall and many other important historical sites

I was a bit disappointed in Love Park. I thought the letters of the "statue/icon" were much larger. In addition, people had climbed up and placed stickers all over the fronts of the letters. One would think that park services would remove these, but they don't bother. So it looks trashy. Furthermore, the water in the fountain behind the Love "statue" was dyed a hideous shade of nuclear blue. Finally, there were vagrants, prostitutes, etc.lingering about the area. It was just nasty!

Yeah, yeah I know it is cliche but who cares?!? The pic I got with my hubs there is one of my favorites. I don't know if we will ever have the opportunity to do it again so at the sake of "looking like a tourist" (which...you are!) just take the photo.

Small but mighty! Of course you have to get a picture with the famous sign, but there is also a lovely fountain which, I'm told, has water in different colors for certain holidays. There are planters with built in benches everywhere, and many of them are shaded and make an excellent lunch spot. The visitor center is here, and it is near a SEPTA and a Philly Phlash stop. As introductions to the city go, this is a great one.

This was the only site in the city that didn't meet or exceed my expectations. This has a sketchy crowd around it, the water is dyed a strange blue color, and the love statue is way smaller than expected.

Love park is not much more than a big concrete square with a cool iconic Philadelphia statue to take a touristy photo. This is a good pit stop to find gourmet lunch trucks during the week. Don't plan on a lot of time here, but it is an easy stop when visiting some other close by attractions: City Hall, Comcast Building, etc.

A must place for a photo op, However, the Park is packed with homeless people, One insisted taking our picture under the Love statue with my iPhone. I was a little uncomfortable handing over my phone to a stranger but it turned out okay. He was very nice and did not beg but did say tips were appreciated.

It's a must visit for the perfect picture moment in the city. There are people in queue and also people who are willing to take a photo for you. After the visit take a dip in the fountain behind. It's so much fun and I am sure not many cities allow it.

I guess we just though this would be more ... just more! The statue is small and located in a park that locals say is in line for a long-overdue renovation. People hanging around the park taking photographs (and asking for tips) were aggressive and made the whole experience uncomfortable. The sculpture itself is smaller than you'd expect and while still iconic, seems a bit whimsical in a city where The Thinker and other Rodin masterpieces can also be seen for free.
Dirty, Dirty, Filthy! Nothing here was pretty, clean or an attraction! Landscaping was nonexistent! trash everywhere....spent about 5 minutes there!

A couple people I asked said that Love Park was nothing special, but I absolutely adored it! People were polite and lined up in an orderly fashion to take pictures in front of the sign, people of all ages enjoyed wading in the gorgeous fountain behind it, and it was overall just a lovely stop in Philadelphia. A must-see if you're just walking around the city.
We were able to get a great photo at the LOVE statue and had a bit of splash time in the fountain. Nice to take a few moments and enjoy a beautiful day in the city of brotherly love.

While actually being the John F Kennedy Plaza it has been nicknamed "Love Park" due to the famous LOVE STATUE designed by Robert Indiana. I have to wonder just how many lovebirds have had their pic snapped by that statue??

Interestingly enough the park was designed by Kevin Bacon's father, City Planner Edmond Bacon to cover an underground parking site (1965) and later in 1969 the fabulous fountain was added.
Love park is an iconic spot to take a photo... There are always a ton of people here. The love statue isn't as large as some imagine it to be though. Very close to city hall.

We first went to the Love park around noon, but there was a line-up, therefore we left and went to visit other areas of the city. We came back later in the evening and there was much less people and we were then able to take pictures.
It's a nice little park during the day, but the crowd it different at night.

Near the Convention Center we parked in a garage and walked a few blocks to get a pic of this iconic sign. Much smaller than the one in NYC, but a great pic nonetheless. Next block over there are photo ops with giant Monopoly Pieces (Iron and Hat) and game pieces (Sorry) and it's in eyeshot of the Reading Railroad. Pretty cool to see.

I thought there would be more to this park than a sculpture and a fountain. The sculpture is just like one across the street from my husband's job so I wasn't going to stand in line to take a picture in front of it but the fountain was cool. It was much higher than most other fountains and the pool was huge. There were children actually swimming in it.
Very cool attraction in downtown Philadelphia. Yeah, it's a touristy thing to do, but it's still cool.

The statute itself is a whole lot smaller than I thought it was going to be. The ripoff of it in NYC is much larger and sits on the ground. This one is on a stand about 6' off the ground. Mind you, the background for this LOVE statute is much nicer with the fountain behind it. The water was coloured a vibrant blue when we were there.

The small park it is in is a bit sketchy with some troublesome looking folks hanging out. So go during the day. It is a busy tourist area so I was a bit surprised the city doesn't have more of a police presence here.

Great selfie and photo opportunity, although you do have to line up for a selfie. There is some entertainment there as well - there were two silver Cowboys standing perfectly still until someone approached.
This is a terrible place in our opinion. In the day time is if terrible and at night I can not imagine how worse it is. Love park and PC fountain of urban mush.

Much smaller than I envisioned. Lots of skateboarders and a few homeless people when we visited. We basically didn't linger, took a few photos and continued on our way. Could definitely use some sprucing up.
Beautiful statue. Great place to visit. Sometimes there is a themed festival in the area. Makes for a great picture!

We enjoyed splashing in the pond the most at this place! There is shallow pond in which children were actually swimming. We definitely did not swim but used this chance to roll up our pants and get into the water. It was indeed relaxing on a hot day! Coming to the main highlight of this area - the 'LOVE' sign, is a photo op. And we had to stand in a queue to wait for our chance to take a picture with the sign, which is fine because that's the best way everyone can get a chance to click a good picture with the famous sign. Don't miss the picture name board on the state building adjacent to this place. A good and enjoyable half hour was spent here!
I honestly assumed it was a big statue,but it's very small.You have the option of taking photos underneath the statue,but you have to wait in line.

its pretty much a little park where you can go an chill for a few hours, on a hot day when they turn the water on its perfect to stay cool, nice atmosphere right in the heart of the city u get a 360 view of the city in a sense great for photos under the love sign, but you gotta watch out for skateboarders tho they visit from time to time.
It makes a nice photo. A few dodgy people about but it didn't feel dangerous. I wouldn't sit there or have a picnic. Just take photo and leave to a better park.
Had to stop by Love Park and get a picture of it's iconic LOVE sign. Beautiful and clean in downtown Philadelphia. Grab an authentic cheese steak and enjoy people watching in the park!

We did the hop on and hop off bus tour and got off at this spot. Got off at this spot and absolutely loved it. It's worth stopping at and taking pictures. There are people usually there who offer to take pictures of you. Just remember to tip them.

If you really need the picture of the Love Sculpture, then do it, but I'd recommend leaving as soon as possible!

There were skateboarders dangerously zipping around with no regard to anyone's safety (including there own).

There was a lady wearing an empty case of M&M's as a hat CREEPILY and intrusively photo-bombing everyone she could.

And as my sheltered 11 year old said: "Wow, this must be THE place to nap in Philadelphia", as an unintentional commentary on the several dozen homeless people.

The fountain and sculpture are beautiful, however there are "locals" hovering nearby and will infringe on your personal space. They will ask if you'd like them to take your photo then require payment for doing so (with your device) or if you do not require their "services" they lightly harass.
This is a great area for a photo and then continue on your way. The area is dirty and has many homeless people and many skateboarders around. There is a general unsafe feel to the location.
Dirty and full of skateboards. Always a long line to get a photo. There are many better sports for a photo like city hall or the art museum
Stumbled on this place on our way to see the Cathedral. The fountain was spraying purple water and it was so relaxing to sit and watch the water.
This aprk turns into one of the best Christmas Markets in the area. Great food and stores to browse through. Also has some good entertainment and a huge Christmas tree in the middle.
Really not sure what the deal is here except a strange pink fountain. Red bull were doing a gallery event thought is was something to do with that.

Made sure to make a visit to JFK Plaza and love park , to enjoy another of Philly's beatiful sites during the Susan G. Komen. Three day walk weekend.

While trying to take a picture if my wife and friends, in front of the LOVE statue. I was berated by several locals trying to get Me to hand over my 600 dollar phone, so they could take a picture with myself included in the picture. After polity trying to take my pictures and move along. I was harassed about not being willing go along with there plans.

I observed them doing this for others only to ask for a tip or hand out. I was also asked, not so polity to move out of the way for other people, when there was no one else standing around waiting, all by the same group how were pestering us from the beginning.

Unfortunately did not stay long to enjoy much of the oher sites in the park. Other than the beatiful spray on pink water from the parks center fountain.

Very iconic and does not disappoint! People will be there offering to take your picture for you for tips - just do it. They really aren't any more likely to steal your phone/camera than any other random person you might ask to take the pic and they need the money. The photo I got with my friends under the statue will be a great memory for me to cherish. For sure worth a stop.
The LOVE statue itself is actually kind of small. When we were here there was a cool little festival going on. A lot of small shops and street vendors.

Very excited to have the chance to visit this:)
My GF and I took a photo under the statue. We also took photos for many other couples in the area.
We went during the Winter time, it was a beautiful view.

As with a lot of major cities, this sign is a huge tourist attraction. My girlfriend and I make it a point to try and take a picture with it whenever we travel to add to the album. When we visited it was not too crowded.

Festive lights, sweet smell of baked goods and the sweet smell of Glühwein invites you to walk thru the "Love park" with friends, family or your special someone. Authentic German decorations can be purchased in one big tent, but lines where long on Saturday so grab something for kids to do while waiting. Items like Belgian waffles, sweet roasted nuts, chocolate to knotted hats, scarfs, gloves to artwork and candles can be purchased here. It's a nice atmosphere and would recommend comfortable sneakers. Thank you Philadelphia for organizing this Market!

A visitor to Philadelphia cannot miss the Love Park and the famous icon. I visited it during noon time and had trouble photographing the famous 'LOVE' statue with harsh light and either morning or evening would have been better time for photography. The whole area is a photographers' paradise as there are many historic buildings and interesting statues to explore and click!

It's nice to see but there's not much to do aside from see the sculpture. Nice to see but not the end of the world if you miss this.
When I was there, there seemed to be a Christmas Market that was being set up. Maybe at a later date or later in the day that could have also made for a good visit but when I was there, most of the stalls were still setting up.

Wish we had better timing. There was some minor construction for what looked like holiday decorating. But, this is a must see if you are with your significant other especially if on a special occasion. I went with my wife on our anniversary. Plenty of people there to take your picture with your sweetheart under the famous LOVE sculpture

Wonderfull time spent in Love park. The american equivalent of the German Christmas Village was awesome. A beautiful place to have this kind of celebration. altough the Christmas tree wasn't lit you can have taken great pictures. Enjoy the Gluhwein and Remember love isn't perfect but it's a very Nice gift. Al that in the city of brotherly love. Thanks Philly
Across from City Hall it's basically the LOVE sculpture and a tourist information center, little else.

You go here, you take a picture of the LOVE statue, you look at City Hall, which looks good from everywhere, you look at the Art Museum, you leave. All there is to it. One warning: it's full of hoodlums after 4:00
This is a lovely place for a pic of a recognised place in Philly - but nothing else really special. Surrounding area is a bit run down, wouldn't recommend spending too much time here.
This is a very small and busy park. Stop by and get your picture in front of the LOVE statue and go on about your day...........

A very small park in central Philadelphia. There is a nice fountain and a lovely "statue" where every couple wants to have his picture taken. Ageable at a sunny day. Good to relax for a moment but don't expect too much of it

We've always wanted to visit the park. Because we came in December the park is also the site of Christmas Village. There were vendors for merchandise as well as food and traditional spiced wine. The spirit was exhilarating. Don't miss this site!
Nothing very unique about it. However, it is a nice place to get a feel of the pulse of Philadelphia. Lots of tourist traffic + the customary photo op.

Every year from late November until Christmas love park becomes Christmas village. You can still take pictures at the iconic statue, but also shop for lots of hand made Christmas gifts as well. Santa is also available for visits.

This place was literally transformed being crowded with multitudes of tents and sheds, offering a rich diversity of goods and souvenirs : Vanilla and Cinnamon Hot-chocolate, holiday sweets, paintings, accessories, scarfs, and Christmas trees. It's the kind of place one takes pleasure in walking around and mingling when not bound by any urgent assignments.

I was visiting US during Christmas last year and got the opportunity to visit Love Park, although worth the wait, you have to go through a hard time to find a good parking spot, and since it was Christmas time, we hardly got 2 mins with the Love sign, as there was a long cue of people waiting to get a photograph! If you do go during this time, at the carnival that happens , do not miss out on their waffles!

Every year after Thanksgiving, Love Park is transformed into Christmas Village. There are an assortment of little stalls that sell a wide variety of gifts and foods. This is a fun way to get into the holiday mood. Drink some of the hot wine from Chaddsford Winery, check out the large assortment of ornaments at Kathe Wohlfahrt, or peruse through the various specialty shops for that one-of-a-kind gift for a loved one. Only a few blocks from the Comcast Building where you can see the Holiday Spectacular or the skating ring and new shops at Dilworth Park. Within walking distance to Macy's Christmas Light show, Dickens Christmas Village, and the Wanamaker Organ. An easy way and low cost way to get into the Christmas mood!

was great visiting the Love park which is an important part of Philadelphia, the city of Love. When visiting, just be very careful not to give your camera or phone to the people around there who want to take you a picture. Just be very careful.

We arrived just in time to see the Christmas Market.
I will warn you, there are unsavory characters near the statue who will attempt to take your picture for you...for a price. We avoided this by teaming up with the family behind us, we took theirs and they took ours.
Teamwork People!! :) Show one another a little love :)
Robert Indiana's iconic LOVE sculpture overlooks this plaza, which also features a fountain. A good to see location, but overcrowded with cars parked along the walls in most places.

The sign is iconic and I expected so much more. However, the sign is small and the park itself is surrounded by skaters and homeless. Sometimes there's a guy dressed as Jesus walking around giving advice. My thought is…its sometime to go to just to say you saw it, took a photo, and left. Not really a place I'd make a special trip for.

While walking to the Reading Marketplace, I spotted LOVE PARK. I was excited!!! To my surprise, the homeless situation was an absolute ASTONISHMENT. Along the back walls, they all pelt & sat with large black garbage bags. I thought NYC have a bad homeless issue but never did I think other cities have it far worse!!! Love park was NOT what I expected but the lovely holiday vibe was there to enjoy. The vendors need to know that most people (of various nationalities) are not from the area. We hold funds to make the purchases simply because we are able. One vendor didn't bat an eye of acknowledgment to my question when I asked about the stained glass items. I could've been Obama's keen, it seemed to not had mattered. A word everyone selling goods: MY HARD EARNED MONEY HAS NO COLOR BARRIERS. IT SPENDS OR NOT SPENDS JUST LIKE THE NEXT WORKING CLASS PERSON'S!! If you don't want it, don't remain in business!!!

Nothing hugely spectacular. You pay overpriced rates to park your car, walk up to this park which is also where the area's homeless population resides, see the Love sign, get bombarded by con artists who offer to take photos of you in front of the sign using your phone, walk back to your car and wonder why you wasted your time. If this is a must see for you, try to take Septa in to avoid the parking chaos. Otherwise, just buy a postcard and save yourself the trip.

We really enjoys the lights and festive atmosphere. It was a little crowded but it goes to show you the draw of the festivities. The nice thing was that they didn't charge admission like the Christmas market in Baltimore.

Love Park has undergone quite a beautiful transformation into a Christmas Village for the Holiday Season centered by a gargantuan beautifully lit tree, dozens of nice quality pop up shops, food vendors, christmas tree lots, and Santa visits all day of course. It is extremely festive and a GREAT time for all ages. It is a perfect event to have in center city to break up the mundane of everyday. It is pronounced by a large nativity scene as well to remind us all of the Reason for the Season. The park is well lit at all times and well patrolled so as to maintain a safety for all its guests. Either as a local or a tourist, definitely stop in and support it....it is well-deserved!
The hype may have set my expectations too high. Both the statue and the village seemed like average things to find in a city--not unique but worth a visit if in downtown Philadelphia.
Love Park Christmas Market is Worth the Effort to visit. There are numerous shops you would find at a typical Christmas market and food retailers.

This was a lot of fun. We really enjoyed walking around eating yummy food and enjoying the sites. The vendors have really unique stuff. Prices are good and you can haggle. Avoid the spiced wine. Smells great tastes like syrup. Mugs are cools I get one at the coffee spot. Cheaper than the wine.
The park isn't astounding, and I've never been a huge fan of the statue, but it is a nice attraction to see at least once.

Oh the masses of people just detract from this attempt to replicate a real European Christmas Market. At times you can't even walk! Lines for food, then where to you eat? I guess if you can't make the Vienna Market, this may do. And why not illuminate the LOVE sign at night so pictures can be special?

We really enjoy Love park in the summer as a central point of departure for visiting Philadelphia's many attractions. In warm weather it's the perfect place to start a stroll up the Parkway towards the many museums and for the holidays they set up an extensive Christmas Village with a variety of shops and eateries.
It is a small statue of letters representing LOVE. You might stop by if you are in the vicinity but otherwise a total waste of time.

Nice for taking the classic photo in front of the love statue. There was a very nice local man offering to take pictures for people in exchange for a few bucks (said he was homeless, who knows but it was nice nonetheless!) Parking was difficult (ended up using the garage). Skateboarders were EVERYWHERE and that would be my biggest complaint.
This is a Philly must if you visit for the day or live here. Every christmas with the village and the tree makes for a great time.
Downtown at its finest. with the new renovations its a great park to visit and hang out. The sign is a great symbol of Philadelphia! Everyone wants their pic in LOVE park!

It's much smaller than its promotion but hey, if you're touring Philly why not check the box and see it! Lots of couples and individuals were taking photos, so my son and I did the same. It's a good example of placemaking for urban planners. You can make ANY location a tourist stop!
I now have a pretty nice picture collection of these love signs, so it was nice to add to it, but i wouldnt make a detour to go see it... it's just a sign and a fountain…

As a skateboarder on vacation in Philly, I knew I had to visit one of skateboardings most iconic skate spots and take a picture. Technically despite a majority of the cities residents supporting skating and offers of skate shoe companies to keep LOVE open to skaters, skateboarding is banned yet somehow it still happens (shouldve brought my board)

So I went to LOVE, expecting to see some locals skating and willing to talk about how iconic the spot is. I didnt see that. I did however, see many homeless, sketchy people eyeing me, asking for money to take a photo.

Stay out of this shady place if you can. The city needs to kick out these people just like it somehow kicked out all the skaters

The LOVE sculpture, fountain and views of city hall and the Philadelphia Museum of Art are all nice, but the decades-old construction is wobbly and worn. There is little shade/shelter and too much limestone. The best thing going for it is the Christmas Village in Nov-Dec.

The best part of the park once was the influx of skateboarders from around the world who loved the park until the city said they were a nuisance. Once they were gone, it became a campground for the homeless. (Good work, city council)

It is getting ready for a complete makeover and should look fantabulous in about 18 months (summer 2017) so watch for the latest postings when you check this review spot out.
It's a nice simple park there are some cool sculptures and jumbo monopoly pieces. There's a line to take a picture at the love sign. It's a very relaxing park. A great place to have lunch and chill.
I love JFK Plaza (Love Park) and the Christmas Village is so cool! Lots of great one of a kind pieces, highly enjoyed it!

This is one of the photo-ops that you need to hit -- just for old time's sake. The park is nice and kept clean. I was there last Saturday and it was REALLY cold, but there were still quite a few people out. I got a cup of coffee from across the street and watched a few young boys skateboard.

We figured sine we were in Philadelphia we had to stop at LOVE PARK on lovers day. We went just to snap a pic under the Love sculpture. Parking was easy, found a spot right across the street for free. Since it was winter and about 19 degrees we made it a quick trip. When we got to the fountain, which was empty due to it being winter we witnessed about 100 skateboarders taking over the park. They were everywhere, even lit a bonfire to keep warm. The LOVE sculpture has stickers and graffiti on it. The park was dirty with litter. I Would like to visit in the summer when the fountain is going. Hopefully next time it wont be crowded with skateboarders.
So ugly and it looked dirty. The love sign had stickers and writing on it. Please don't waste your time! There was absolutely nothing nice about it.

The Love Park is truly a unique place that is worth visiting at least once. There one can meet people from all over Philly. One can see wealthy parents with children talking with people experiencing homelessness. Its a really a great place to meet people from all walks of life. People are generally friendly and there to have a good time. It is a city park in an urban environment so one should always be aware of those around you.

I thought the Love sign would be BIGGER - it is very small and easy to miss. We went in the winter so the fountain was not on - I am sure the park is much more appealing when it is. There were dozens of skateboarders taking over the entire park and making it kind of hard to take pictures. I don't mind them but I could understand how some people would prefer that they weren't so abundant there. There are a lot of homeless in this park also. But, we did meet a very sweet homeless man named George (I think) that says he sleeps in the park and has appointed himself to be in charge of keeping it clean. He took our pictures for us in front of the Love and had surprisingly fantastic picture taking skills!

Nice idea for all, the LOVE, the fountain but the area hasn't been the best place to mingle because of some selected locals who live "here"won't leave you along or wi;; ask for somet . Take some pictures, walk around, and go somewhere else.
I think that this was a very moving public art piece for all to take in and appreciate. There was a line quite long with lovers who were posing for pictures in front of this art installation.
Love is part of our life..but sometimes you should show off that love...Go to Love Park you will definitely love it..best time to go at thanksgiving and Christmas ...😊
LOVE makes this a must see and take pictures attraction. Expect to wait for for tourists and locals as they all take pictures!
Love park is a park. It's nice, crowded, right in the city. But the LOVE statue is what makes it a must see. Philly does a great job carrying the theme throughout.
I wouldn't come here just for the sign. But it's adjacent to city hall, the Masonic temple, and close to the observatory. Iconic and free.

When you think of Philadelphia, a few images comes to mind:
- Liberty Bell
- Independence Hall
- The Rocky Balboa steps (for some)
- Cheesesteaks
- And the LOVE sculpture.

My group had limited time to see the touristy stuff, and I made it a point to make this a stop. One person said the Rocky steps had AMOR, but that's not LOVE (in English).

We came here on a chilly February, and the park was under construction. Our driver dropped us off at the curb of this busy busy area and circled the park. In front of the LOVE sculpture was a trowel and shovels, and the cops told us the mayor was breaking ground to re-do the park. It was going to be a media fest at 11 am, but we didn't have time to hang around for an hour.

We got a photo of the iconic statue. I would give it 5 stars if parking weren't so difficult.

Arguably one of the most Philly spots in the city. It's a definite walk through situation on the way to the art museum with no need to stop for longer than 30 seconds unless it's during the holidays during which time the Christmas village has shops set up where you can buy tasty food and other items. Usually a 3, during the holidays it's a 4.5.
This is the place where and my soon to be wife shared one of our first dates. As you can no doubt tell that was amazing of course. Right in center city, right by the city hall...Lovely area.

The LOVE Park (aka the iconic JFK Plaza) is located in Center City.

Pack your camera for the photo opp and get your picture taken in front of the LOVE sculpture. Then have lunch by the fountain and stop in to see the Fairmount Park Welcome Center and Gift Shop.

PLEASE NOTE!

Apparently, Love Park is undergoing renovation and is closed to the public until Spring 2017. During the construction process, the LOVE sculpture has been moved to nearby Dilworth Park temporarily.
When you are anywhere near center city Philly, you have to stop and get your picture taken at the LO VE architecture. It is a classic in it's own rite and has been as long as I can remember.
The sign was moved due to the parking being remodeled. The history of the famous sign was truly interesting.

Love Park is basically only worth visiting if you want a picture in front of the LOVE sculpture. There are nicer fountains down Benjamin Franklin Pkwy, which you can walk down to get to the Academy of Natural Sciences, the Free Library of Philadelphia, the Franklin Institute, the Barnes, and the PMA. This park is right near City Hall so you can get a lot of sights in at once.
Pretty much the only attraction here is taking a selfie with the giant LOVE sculpture, and JFK boulevard in the background.

Great place for relaxing with friend and made photos with your LOVE
Love Park is so lovely place, enjoy in it
We took some really cool photos in front of the LOVE sign. It really does make for a super cool photo opt.
Well, it was not in its usual place, moved for construction, but a must do. Got the picture and moved on.
The sign is a great place to affirm your love with loved ones! I think the park itself is under reconstruction.
Great place for a quick photo op. This is a a must when visiting Philly. It's right in the middle of the city and an easy quick visit on the way to other attractions.
Nice place to visit winter or summer, nice for family, places to eat, shopping area . On the summer the have the fountain on.
I ran around taking pictures even though it was raining. I loved all the large statues. It was really exciting for me as a photographer.
Hop in the line to get a quick picture, and then move along. Not much to see of do. Be wary of the locals who'll want to take your picture for money or tips. Fun for the kids.

I LOVE Philadelphia, there is so much to do and enjoy. You can spend two active weeks sight seeing and keep saying "WAW"

This park is a twenty minutes visit, no more. It is nice to see.

It was a must photo stop for us, especially because it was so close to our hotel. We got there too early though so the fountain wasn't on yet. But besides a quick photo, there isn't much else left for there to do.

My husband and I were walking through Philly on a cool autumn day and passed this park. Just had to stop in to get a photo. It was fairly quiet, only had to wait for one other person to take a photo. The fountain was off because it was November I guess, but it was still a nice shot.
A great little park in the city with the iconic LOVE sign. We were there close to Thanksgiving, so the Christmas Village was there. It was fun to browse through the different shops.

Sign is very small! I always assumed it was bigger from pictures. The park is also temporary closed so it's located by City Hall which is very busy and congested. I say put the original in a museum and build a bigger one!!!

This actual park is under construction and the city gardens department have got the plans underway. Some plantings has been done.The famous statue has been moved to City Hall Central Square. It is still a great photograph opportunity. The Love Park nearby Visitor Centre is well worth a look

This is one of the 3 photo ops you must do in Philadelphia, the other is the Liberty Bell and the Rocky statue. This is right by City Hall and everybody takes pictures, just ask someone to take your picture and they'll gladly do it, It's fun and free and only takes a second
The park not there anymore :( so sad why did they do that? the love statue is moved to the front of city hall you can still visit it and take pictures.
This is such a famous and iconic image that I expected a lot more when I saw it. It is very small and the park is rather sketchy as well.
must see because it's so iconic but was rather a disappointment... it looked bigger on the post card :)

I had seen this structure in Philly postcards and images, and expected it to be a large structure. Honestly, it is rather small and just sitting in one corner near city hall. But still, respect the thought of Brotherly Love, which this signifies.

Good to click a picture and walk on.
The most inconic thing about Love Park is the sign. But the park is in downtown Philly and who doesn't love the area all around here. On a beautiful day I would stay here 12 hours!!

Boooo! Yes the love sign is moved across the way and is still available for pictures. But that's not love park. They should have left well enough alone. It was a very cool place. Skaters or not. I was disappointed to see that it was ripped apart to make a new "garden park".
This attraction has moved across the street. The park is being renovated. The new temporary setting is OK. I would suggest waiting until the park is reopened.

I could not wait to finally see the famous love sign but when i saw the city hall building i got more impressed haha
It's such a nice park
Great for a walk too

Okay the 'LOVE' icon is a photo op that couples/families all flock too. But look over your shoulder and the water spout plaza ...with walkways through the multitudes of synchronized fountains is both fun to walk thru and offers additional great photo ops. As an aside, it is also a major photography site for weddings, so area may be limited on Saturdays.
the Love PARK is located in front of City hall. Its a small park and hte main attraction is the. Love structure. many visitors are coming just to take a picture there..
Very lively and right in the center of the city. Lots of folks taking pictures. The sculptures are a real asset to the feel of the city, but more or less all there is to the park. Very iconic!

The size of this statue surprised us. Ursinus College in nearby Collegeville, Pennsylvania, has a slightly larger version of this statue. Still a nice park and worth seeing if you find yourself in this area of Philly.
The real Love Park was under construction when we arrived, however the "LOVE" sculpture was displayed right next to city hall. Nice spot for some pictures!

a lot of people like luv park but is under renovation right now. they have a water fountain but other than that a lot of homeless people just gather there and hang out. maybe after it is done they might have them relocate somewhere else.

Decent picture, we stayed at the hotel right across from the park so we were able to see this every day. I felt that the park was under whelming, if you are near by stop in but don't make a special trip.

Park is fenced off and in the process of rejuvenation. Looks like a lot of work still to be done. The 'love' statue has been moved to the square where City Hall is. Was totally surprised by how small the 'love' statue is.

Still super adorable but over-run with homeless who are willing to take your photo with your camera for a tip! If you take your own photo they still expect a tip and are willing to get a little too close to remind you of it.

For somebody who is in love and wanted to experience the famous LOVE sign I was not impressed to be 100% honest, it's a very small sculpture and when I got there it was late at night so you couldn't see it well because of the fact it's a park and lighting is low and sculpture is dark red, I recommend visiting during the day.

I have always wanted to see this and take a picture!!! We went to the Liberty bell and walked the 1.2 miles to the sign took our pic walked thru the lil water spray area and walked back the 1.2 miles. So glad to see it. Bucket list check
When in Philly got to get a picture in love park. Right down the street is City hall and history all over. There is usually something going on in the park, go and enjoy it.
Went there on a recent trip to Philadelphia. The location had a sign of currently under renovation..

Took a SEPTA train up with a friend. Because of the construction they'd moved it for a bit. Asked around a few people to try and pinpoint its location. We ended up walking sort of passed it, looping around the square then coming back around to find the Love statue. We found it. Took some pictures to prove we'd been there then walked around a bit more. I don't know it it's been moved back by now. This was back in February.
I think this park has become a symbol of Philly, but overall is overrated. It is worth seeing, it is a good spot to relax and enjoy the people watching, but it is not really a destination in itself.

I used to live in Philadelphia- the last four months of my stay I would walk from West Philadelphia to Old City- passing by the Love Park often. Lovely place to take a picture of yourself and gaze at the fountain which is sometimes dyed a nice bright hue. This is definitely a daytime trip, but for the brave, the evenings are fine.

So we were staying around the corner at the Marriott Hotel (which I highly recommend by the way). From the hotel you can walk to the LOVE Park. The sign is located on the same grounds as City Hall. So if you're looking at the front of City Hall, the LOVE sign will be to your left. You go to the sign and take pictures underneath it. What makes this park more interesting is that there is a live "Jesus" also located in the park. This "Jesus" character is there almost every day. He wears a robe with a rope belt, his hair is long and he has a beard. He resembles the European version of Jesus that many of us are familiar with. He delivers a message, speaks on scripture, just like Jesus did. He will talk with you and take a picture with you. He's worth seeing. I think he's in the right place. After all wasn't the message of Jesus about LOVE?!
Just a place to look at people and take some pictures in the city of brotherly Love. This location is walking distance to just about everything.
The area is amazing, There was not a lot of line when we visited. There are fountains for kids to play in. Fun for family.
very busy area. a lot of people. middle of downtown. taking pictures can be a challenge but orderly. if you get hungry restaurant everywhere and shopping closeby.
Just the sign and a fountain. Not much really to comment on. Take a photo and move on. I think they might be renovating the area.
Got a great photo in front of the Love sign....it is now located across the street since construction is being done at the park. A really nice guard took our picture. Pretty cool!
So I went downtown Philly to find that the LOVE park is undergoing some work and the LOVE statue was moved to the plaza just outside city hall. No worries, easy to get a picture with the LOVE.
The place was super crowded. Nearly impossible to get a picture in front of the sculpture and it was TINY. Don't go out of your way for this.

This park is a great place for families to come enjoy an afternoon in the summer. There are fountains that randomly spray to keep the kids cool. We were here during July 4th week and there was a large Airstream food truck and there is also a Starbucks (which us air-conditioned). The sculpture us on one end if the park, and people were enjoying a romantic photo op.
The sign was smaller then I thought it would be! Grabbed a couple selfies and continued on my way. Perfect addition to the city of brotherly love!

It was really small garden and I expected to see a bigger love sign. It's a small love sign in a small garden in the middle of the street and there are some other interesting things around. I still like it

I wouldn't go out of my way to see this. It's cute to see as you pass by. Proceed with caution. While frequented by tourists and skaters, the park is also popular with the homeless and drug users. While non of those groups of people are outright deliberately dangerous, the park has had some crime on and off so be guarded and keep the visit brief.
It is there and free and great for couples to have their picture taken by, but otherwise just a sign

When I visited the previous spring it was an enjoyable park to stop at, take some pictures, and soak in the atmosphere of Philadelphia. But when I returned in December there was a Christmas Village going on that made the park so crowded it was nearly impossible to even move. We tried to explore a little bit but it took too long to walk through even a little section of the park and we couldn't get close enough to any of the vendors to consider buying anything. It seemed like a neat little Christmas marketplace but was unfortunately just too crowded to enjoy at all. I usually don't have a problem dealing with crowds; we just didn't have the hours to spend there that it would have taken to see anything.

This is a really nice park and was full of hustle and bustle when I visited it on a lovely hot Sunday afternoon. The sculpture is nice to see but I was expecting it to be bigger - perhaps because I've seen the version in New York. Still a great place to visit though. If you want your photo taking under the sculpture it looks like there is usually quite a queue.
One of my favorite places in the US. Enjoyed strolling and enjoying an afternoon watching people come and go. I felt the "love".

I can honestly say pictures make it seem so big. Thank goodness I was staying at a local hotel that knew exactly where it was. Very small on top of a steel stool. Don't know when they are moving it, so make sure and ask before going.
We visited this sign just today and just realized it has been temporarily moved to City Hall. Nonetheless, it is something to see if you're seeing the city. Cute!
I thought the LOVE sculpture would be bigger but around it is very beautiful! I love the water place people can walk through very cooling!

Stopping here is a great Philly photo opp but, that is about it. The park "is" currently being renovated and the statue has been temporarily relocated.
This is a nice park to visit during the Christmas season when it hosts a Christmas Village with snacks, ciders, cocoa and adult beverages to sample while you shop.
The sign is a lot smaller than expected, but it's the original. Other cities have larger one that are more familiar.
Nice little place to sit and people watch. Great for kids too. The fountains were a big hit and lots of places to sit.
Great sculpture located outside of the beautiful City Hall building. Wonderful spot for picture taking.

Nothing wrong with walking by to see the famous sculpture by Robert Indiana or nothing wrong with a quick hop off a tour bus to do the same. You probably won't be overcome with awe, but while you are in this great neighborhood, pass by and give this a glance.
They had moved the LOVE sign to a different park because of renovations to the park. We had no idea just how small the sign is, I know that isn't a big deal but it was a little underwhelming for us.

Designed by Robert Indiana, the sculpture spells out 'Love'. It is one of the sites we visited on our hop on hop off tour. We learned that Indiana did not have a trademark on the sculpture so he never got any royalties from it.
It sits in a corner of a large piazza near a water fountain park, it makes up for a nice photo-op.
Love Park is within walking distance to Reading Terminal Market, City Hall and numerous other sites to see in Philly. Get your camera ready.

It is a free site - it is a small sign so don't be shocked. It is conveniently located though so see it when you are doing other sites. Walk through city hall - visit sign and leave - yeah I was shocked - sketchy at night for sure:( But thankfully I did not run in to any issues.

It's only small but the word says it all. You have to have your picture taken by it! It's a lovely spot with nearby cafe and seating. Kids running in and out of nearby water fountains. Lovely experience on a warm Philadelphia afternoon.

The sign was much much smaller than I imagined. It is dwarfed but the size of square in which it resides and the fountain behind it. But it is a must do while in Philly. Luckily it is on or near the hop on hop off bus route.

well, I went for a walk after having dinner with friends and one of us said lets take some pictures under the love sign! for fun we went there, it was around 10pm or so... the city was so quite and creepy with punch of homeless ppl around the sign at the park offering to take photos for anyone who comes there!! I mean it happened that we saw a few girls getting harassed by a junkie and they only got away from him as they ran out of the park! my ADVICE is to visit the park at day time! :) although it wasn't that much of a thing to do if I may say!

ALL the LOVE to whom ever is gonna read this :)

0_o Im from NY, we make things BIG so when i came up to the famous love sign.....i was shocked it was soooo smalll! If you want to take a picture fine but we ended up playing mini gold at Franklin square and the love sign there is much more satisfying... was kinda surprised.
Great place to take pictures. Kids had a blast taking loving pictures in front of the famous love monument.
walk and enjoy the many adventures that love park have to offer open your eyes and drink in the sounds and lot more a few hours will give you love love and a happy days adventure!!!!!!!!

I went early in the morning, took a picture of this iconic piece. No biggie, passed by later and there was a line about 20 deep waiting to photograph.Not a must see, but with so many thing right in the area why not.
I am not a romantic person son the topic about love is not my thing but if you go to Philadelphia is good that you stop by the love park and take a picture.

I would like to insert the word about this place. Park of Love - a small square near the Town Hall, famous for its sculpture by Robert Indiana "Love", created in 1978. This place has become a popular symbol of the "city of brotherly love", his image can be seen in every corner of the city. 20-foot sculpture is very simple - the letter L O V E, put on one another. The area occupied by half a fountain. From the land of streams of water alternately occur in which swarming children of different ages. This is a nice place where you can sit in the summer heat. Since November, at this point, make an ice rink. Decorated trees with lights, music create a romantic atmosphere for skiing. People here are always a lot. Especially in the evening. At Christmas there is fair. Every weekend here there are interesting activities.
If you are close by or walking by it's definitely worth the stop to take a few pictures! Great photo opportunity!
Love Park in Philly is where the most people want to find LOVE and take pictures of it, with themselves, of course! It helps people to understand - what is LOVE?

We went and took the required photos. This would make a great spot for a couple to get engaged or go on a date. For us, it will be added to the holiday card because the picture is too darn cute to pass up when you're with someone you love! It's also a great area to stroll and enjoy the atmosphere of the city and the beautiful buildings surrounding you.
Smaller than expected, "hustlers" posing as tourists offered to take our picture, then asked for donation. Concert going on, he and his wife probably cleaned up!

I was so excited to bring my daughters here, however I was so disappointed with how SMALL the actual piece is! Pictures are very deceiving. We walked right past it at first. We saw it and we were over it in a minute. Nothing else really that exciting to do in the area.

This is not a place to kick back and relax. I am a lifelong Philadelphia resident and this "park" is a hub for "swarming" You could be sitting there and suddenly find yourself surrounded by hundreds of young teens hellbent on trouble. Imagine if you were on a date or out with your family. There is also a racial aspect to it. Maybe it would be okay in the winter or in daylight, but stay out at night

The Love Park is a very lovely Park located in the JFK Plaza and is surrounded by many attractions so it’s worth a visit. It’s next to a very lovely fountain, it’s adjacent to City Hall and the Reading Terminal Market is 3 blocks to the east.
A great place to stop for the classic photo opportunity. Wait your turn in line for your photo in front of the sculpture. Not much otherwise to the park, but still fun and a must-do when in the city.
Disappointed to find that the park is completely zoned off and under construction, nothing but a construction lot.

The park is totally under construction and cannot be visited at all. The parking garage is still open but is a disaster to drive in. I had a prepaid spot and it took over 30 minutes of parking to find an opening.
True it was during flower show but they let me in, how hard is it to stop people from entering if there are no spots.
This is an iconic sign and a great place for a picture. The park was under development, but you could still get to the LOVE sign.

It is located downtown in front of City Hall. We were here this time at Christmas and so we visited the Christmas Market Center and bought some gifts plus we enjoyed watching the skaters on the ice rink. It is a fun place to go and take photos any time of the year. Next time you are in Philadelphia, be sure to take a photo at Love Park.
Very scenic view of Center City Philadelphia. Wonderful water display. Sometimes overcrowded. Easy access from center city hotels. Sometimes music is played on the spring, summer an d fall.
The LOVE Park is being developed. The LOVE signed has moved to City Hall. Still a great photo opportunities if you can find it, which is not too difficult.

I was here with my wife and grown up kids. Just the sight of this signage was enough for us to hold hands and sit under the sign and take lovely pics for lovely remembrance! This is a "Must - See" location, which in Phyladelphia.

This is a great place to take a photo, but it's a pretty small area. It was also pretty crowded when i came through. I hear it is currently under construction, so the iconic sign may no longer be there.
This is an ideal picture taking spot so go early to avoid people in your shot or long waits to take a picture,
Its under construction so there is nothing to see except a large dirt field. Hope the statue comes back so others can get a pic under the love sign in the city of brotherly love.
The park is under construction and the love sculpture packed away. Oh well. I walked around instead.
Love Park is under construction. The famous sign is not there. Look for the " Amor" sign on Embassy row.
We visited the LOVE state at Dilworth Park - the JFK Plaza is under construction. This is only a few blocks from the Reading Terminal Market.
Love Park is a pile of dirt right now. They also removed the statue until the park is done. I wish they would have relocated the statue to another accessible location until the park is done. Oh well.
Famous for Philly, if you're just visiting definitely stop by for a photo in front of the LOVE statue. I will warn you, (to me at least) it's a little underwhelming. Worth it for the photo though.

The site is under massive contruction. We had spent 15 minutes walking around the area Googling, finally were lucky enough to be tood by the construction workers that the LOVE statue would be back once the park renovation is done.

Love Park was nice. It is worth seeing but I wouldn't list it on the top 10 things to see in Philly. Its easy to get to and is in walking distance of several other attractions, making it worth a look. You can take some pics and move on.

We enjoyed two hours strolling around the Christmas Village in Love Park in the early evening. Some unique vendors and traditional German goods all festive and lit up for Christmas. Great was to get in the Christmas spirit.

During a walking tour we learned that the famous LOVE statue was moved from the park while it’s being renovated.

The purpose of our visit was to stroll around the Christmas Market - which helped to set the holiday mood.

The market is also located across the way at City Hall where you can see a light show every night starting at 5:30pm.

Went to the Christmas village in Philadelphia for the first time today. It is spread out between Love Park and Dillworth plaza. There is a convenient parking garage under Love park where you can park for $11 if you get there early enough. We spent about 2 hours or so wandering around checking out the stalls and enjoying the food. We got there early enough, around 11:30 in a Sunday, where things weren’t super crowded yet. We ate the raclette cheese sandwiches which were awesome especially with the mulled wine! Nice German and Russian crafts as well as tons of local artisans displaying their goods. Glad we went and will likely go again next year!

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the Christmas Village! There are so many GREAT vendors with unusual products and great gifts! Def checkout booth #1 Silk Road with AMAZING mosaic lanterns! And the Chadds Ford Mulled Wine is AWESOME! I come every year & would never miss it, with music, food, and treasures from all over the world!
It is nowhere to be found. Not even a temporary locale while the whole park is under construction. Maybe next time.

I read a lot about this but unfortunately due to construction this sculpture is missing from its original place. There is not much information available where it is though we did looked at Delaware Plaza but no luck.

This is a spot you have seen in many movies and tv shows so it was fun to experience. I was glad to see it and take a pic in front of it. Not much else going on but it is still a great thing to say you seen it and was by it.

was on our list of things to see but the park is under reconstruction- we were told that the deadline was September 2017 but it was no where near ready so they were not sure when it would reopen- if you are looking to catch a bus there don't the stop is not available at this time

We were so disappointed to find the Love statue is not currently on display. It's being refurbished.
I had read on TA that you could still see it at City Hall, but this is not the case.
Maybe we'll get back to Philadelphia some day and get to see it.
This is an outdoor park and it is currently being renovated. It is not able to be visited at this time. LOVE statue has been removed due to renovations.

Homeless people? What homeless people? I didn't even see any last time I was there for the Philadelphia Christmas Market. It was a very pleasant time, with McDonald's-ified versions of many international treats like traditionallike french crêpes, authentish döner kebabs, reheated belgee-I-wish-the-employee-working-the-stand-gave-a-flying-fig-an waffles (AKA liege-ish waffles), and hot $5 cocoa to wash it all down.

Even with the cheesy knock-off versions of the aforementioned foods, the market does offer legitimate German-made traditional Christmas items. Principal among them are the Weihnachtspyramide (Christmas pyramids with the vanes on top that spin if you light candles below), Schwibbögen (hand-carved Christmas arches), and Räuchermannl (wooden figures that appear to be smoking pipes when you burn an incense cone in their bellies). Several of the event staff are actually German, and speak German, which is very refreshing to hear.

The park itself has undergone significant renovation, including removal of the fountain. I can't guarantee that you will not not be unaccosted by people who make this park tbeir semi-permanent residence, but go check it out anyway; it's worth a gander. Just don't go alone at night. It can get a wee bit less than comfortable if you're not used to dealing with the kids of folks you find out on the streets at times of day or night, when those who are fortunate have homes are aldeady inside, battened down for the night. Just bring a few friends along, and you should have a fine time. :-)

Also, it's fun to go around the corner, & visot the giant clothes-pin. And don't drive, there's practically nowhere to park close by, unless you want to pay...
We were on a Hop-On Hop-Off tour bus and we stopped off at Love Park to take a break, it was a lovely day, truly enjoyed the park and surroundings. They did have a band playing as well.
We saw the monument while driving thru Philly. It was just easier to drive by and see, as opposed to finding a parking spot.

We have all see the LOVE statue on TV but I had no idea it was so small. This wasn't worth the walk to see it. It is a tiny statue that people wait in a line to take a picture under. Definitely very touristy.

This was awesome to see & would be been even better if my husband and I could be gotten our picture taken there...bit it was soooo busy the day we were there we decided to move on to see something else. Oh well, maybe next time.
Went there long time back. It seems now it is under renovation. At that time it was a small park with famous Love symbol. It's good for taking pictures.
Fun to see just because. Mostly a tourist location but had to take a photo anyway. Cool spot to just look around all of the streets and buildings around you.

My first visit to this market and I was not disappointed, it was very festive and nicely laid out with some wonderful stores. I loved the German eating place for some wonderful German fare on a cold day.
You can buy Gluhwein in a festive mug for $9 and you get to keep the mug. Excellent location and easy to find for first time visitors to the city.
I recommend checking it out if you are in the city for Christmas.
Love Park turns into a cute village at Christmas. The statue is in repair but the place is terrific. City Hall is across the street.so you can go iceskating.

We had a mild, sunny day to enjoy the German Christmas Market's Ice rink, food and vendors! The vendor booths are actually located in Love park and in front of City Hall. A few additional stalls are near the carousel in the City Hall courtyard.

A few vendors were selling pretzels which sadly were nothing like real German pretzels. But the German grill had yummy wurst and potato pancakes!!

Many of the vendors were from Europe and selling authentic wares. Everything from Russian stacking dolls, leather goods, wine, Gluwein, textiles, jewelry, pottery, artwork, wooden wares, ornaments, soaps and candles.

A true taste of Deutschland! 🇩🇪
Nice renovation. A nice sitting area of to the side. Good access to the car park. I do miss the fountain.

It's not much, just that word. An easy quick cross-off of things to see. And who doesn't like a little love on their vacation? It's full of tourists,and everyone when we saw were happy and friendly and offered to take photos of one another. Very near City Hall. After it IS the city of brotherly love.

If you haven't visited this spot, then you don't know too much about Philly! See the people, the musicians, the skateboarders, the busy workers, the busy shoppers, you name it..it's here. If you're coming to Philly, stop by this iconic landmark first thing.
Im a hopeless romantic. Why would I snap a pic next to LOVE!! it was improptu but I enjoyed my 5 min photo session.
Stop by Love Park for a photo opportunity with someone you care about. Parking on the street in front is accessible on the weekend.

The City of Philadelphia has proudly worn this moniker since the time of William Penn in the 17th century. It is therefore fitting that after massive structural renovations the JFK Plaza in Center City near City Hall will now be known as Love Park, proudly fronted by a copy of Robert Indiana’s iconic Love sculpture with the lopsided “O.” I have walked across this plaza innumerable times and went to take a look at the new configuration. With some parts still under construction, dissenting voices are already suggesting that, unlike Philadelphia’s much cherished Rittenhouse Square, the new structure is not a traditional park but a concrete platform that one traverses rather than enjoys. Structural renovation mandated some redesign and the need for greater security might also help explain the rather flat and featureless appearance. I found the new plaza easy to negotiate and while shade providing trees might be missing for now there are ample places to sit under an umbrella, have a coffee or check the messages on one’s cellphone. Eventually two substantial fountains will be added and many programs are being planned to entertain visitors. And similarly to the Rocky statue at the Philadelphia Museum of Art people were lining up to have their photograph taken at at the Love sculpture with the lopsided “O.”

Love Park will be officially dedicated on May 30, 2018. Enjoy your stroll.

While you can see the love sign on the East side of the park, watch out for the drunk, homeless guy who is using the statue of Ben Franklin as his hangout. Things are under construction and generally not very attractive. Let's hope that things change for the summer.
What a nice park, we stopped here on our way back from visiting Independence hall, and the Liberty Bell.
...the park is basically a construction area...and the sign is a little small...after the magic gardens of Philadelphia...another "tourist attraction point" that will definitely disappoint…

We went by on our way to the Art Museum and had to stop for the photos, of both the LOVE and the AMOR statues. Philadelphia is truly an amazing city, and everyone seems to truly embody the “brotherly love” ambience. So many smiley faces and helpful strangers.
I thought it would be some grand thing since I read you had to see this thing. It was small and boring. I always thought this would be huge. What a rip.. Philly you can do better.
I always thought this would be huge, not sure why. It was worth finding but blink and you will miss it.
Very cool public park! Enjoyed the cool down under the fountain and fantastic view of the city! We LOVED Love Park! ❤️

We were staying about 8 blocks away so it was an easy walk. My husband and (very active) 1 year old walked over early evening. It was not overly crowded for a Saturday night. The sign had some people standing around, all being cordial and waiting their turns to take pics. The view from the LOVE sign straight to the Art Museum steps is really incredible. I wish I had a better camera to capture it. The fountain just beyond the sign with the lights was extremely entertaining for our curious 1 year old. He loved running over the lights (just watch the kiddos - staring into those lights would not be a good idea) and it was so hot we let him get as close to the water as he could without getting soaked. One thing to watch out for - lot's of homeless people in the surrounding area! no one bothered us or asked for anything but its always good to be aware. Have fun!

We went to Love Park to see the iconic Love sculpture by Robert Indiana. We parked in China Town for $5 dollars and walked first to Reading Terminal Market then afterwards we made our way down Arch street to Love Park, the line to take a picture wasn't bad and it was a neat experience.

They took away the fountain, and replaced it with a flat surface fountain. It is a lot different than what it was before. Flatter for people with disabilities, places to sit and have lunch, they put the Christmas Village there this past Christmas. Recently turned the fountain on. Come see how it changed.
