It is more a plaza than a park, thought it would be a quieter place - it is a busy little square in the middle of the city and next to the city hall, the welcoming gate of Benjamin Franklin Park. Plus there is the LOVE statue - and another one AMOR on the way through the parkway and to the National Gallery. Interesting place to visit :)

I love the new Love Park. The 2018 redesign opens it up to feel so expansive and inspiring. The openness draws your eye to the horizon where the art museum looks back at you. And when you turn around City Hall looks so pretty. The Robert Indiana sculpture is perfectly situated for fun photo-taking. Thanks Philly!

In the city of brotherly love, I had to find the 'LOVE' art which has been changed to the 'AMOR' art installation. The installation sits on a steel box so that people can stand under it for pictures. This was a great stop. If you love doing totally touristy things where ever you go, this is a MUST stop! A young couple walked up and the guy was trying to take a selfie while under the art but couldn't make it work so I offered to take their picture. A nice stop!

The old Love park scenery in my opinion was a lot more beautiful than the New Love Park. The new Love Park is much cleaner than the old because in the old Love Park is where you would find a lot of the city's homeless population. Now you can come with your family and take your picture with our Love Park Monument. A picture I know that you will admire for the rest of your life and your visit to our city.
We took a leisurely stroll through Philly and walked through this park, very clean and wow, the views were great.

Can't Lie I was expecting more!!! The fountain was not operating when we were there. So maybe that took away from the view. It was nice to see down to the Rocky Steps. But hard to pull into a picture. Need to work some photo magic to remove people in the background of your photos.
Def stop by while walking around city!!

We were disappointed that the fountain wasn't on during one of the hottest days in July! We were happy to snap a few pictures in front of the LOVE sign. There were about 6 people ahead of us in line but it goes quickly. The hop on hop off bus stop is at the corner near Pennsylvania station. Glad we stopped here!

I always wanted to see the park I've seen in print and media. It is nice and good for some photos, but this visit underwhelmed me. There was a dry fountain area. It was hot and sunny and I'm not sure why there wasn't any water. There are tables and chairs and I was thankful for some shade from the umbrella at the table. I got my LOVE sculpture photo, for which you'll probably wait in line. But most folks are happy to take your picture and you'll take theirs. The skyline has some great photo ops, too, as does the area across JFK Blvd with huge board game pieces and other sculptures.
For my chance to get my photo, I give it an excellent rating, but only average for the overall park.

Awesome time in Philly for spring break. When you get to the Love sculpture you need to line up to take a photo, There is a spot (near logan square) with a smaller sculpture in Spanish (amor) where you can take a picture with no line.

We weren't sure what to expect but we checked this out because we were at City Hall and it's right next door. Kids loved the splash park! It's very well kept and wasn't trashy at all. View of the Art Museum is nice from here too. There was a line for photos at the LOVE sculpture so we took photos from the side and behind the line. Would go back for sure!

If you really want to see the sculpture, stop and take the picture. However, there's not much else in this concrete park (unless you count the homeless). It's neat, but then leaves a little to be desired as a meaningful stop.

The old Love Park was a multi level concrete construction with lots of wonderful sharp edges, drops and railings to remove many a tooth, break many a bone and deliver many a concussion as it seemed designed to be the perfect unofficial skate park for the city. As a result the city made skateboarding there illegal, and as a result even the designer took a spin through there to show off his skills.

Two years ago they started renovations with the promise of a new 21st century park. The result, with small and large basin less fountains to delight toddlers and dogs, is a single level granite plane that neither shows off the Love Sculpture to its best nor provides an attractive place for lunch time trysts, summer naps or relaxing breaks to read a book. It’s just a little boring.

By all means take a wander through, then keep going down the parkway to The Franklin Institute or Art Museum. What was once a somewhat anachronistic piece of cityscape is now just plain bland.

Summer in the City….. Slow down and stroll through Love Park. Lots of fun orange seats to relax, maybe a picnic, and enjoy the passers-by. Two ping-pong tables await for friendly games. The fountain is refreshing visually. The architecture, City Hall, a fabulous Tromp L’Oeil Mural on the Meridian Hotel, and the iconic LOVE Sculpture by Robert Indiana offer a panoply of views.

Sit a while and enjoy.

I was under the impression it would have the ‘love’ sign big like they have in other cities with their names. But nope it was tiny, made for you to stand under and not on. The view from the sign was great and the building across the street has some cool toy art but overall i was disappointed.

Also there is very little shade so expect to be in the sun.

This park contains the iconic LOVE statue and is a great photo opportunity. The are often events at the park and food trucks can be found along the edge. Unfortunately, the seems to be a large number of homeless people in and around the park sleeping in mid day.

We went here specifically to get a picture with the LOVE statue. It was smaller than I expected. There was no line to get a picture taken and nobody else around so it was nice to spend some time taking fun and silly pictures. The fountain wasn't operating so we didn't have the nice shot of the statue with the fountain in the back but we still got some great pictures. the park has a nice space to relax with some lounge chairs. It's a nice area with great views of the city!!!
As a tourist in Philadelphia this was on the must see list. As everybody else a picture under the Love sign is a must do.

This park is located diagonal from City Hall across JFK Blvd. There are crosswalks to assist in getting over to it. It isn’t as large as I expected but the Love sign is a great photo opt and people were making use of it. There was plenty of seating and it was a busy place the day we visited.
Large open paved area with smaller greenway, fountain, LOVE sculpture for photos, metal seating of small bistro style tables and ping pong tables to use.
It seemed to be popular with people taking a break from work or their day to catch a little rest and relaxation along with tourists taking pictures.
It appeared they were working on part of it but not sure what that was going to be.
Of course it is noisy as streets are on all sides of it downtown and there wasn't really much shade.
So we just made a quick visit. Do wish I'd taken a picture at the sign though but there was a short line.

It is a small park in Center City. Most tourist go there to take a picture of the Love Sign. I found it to be smaller than the photos I have seen of the sign. The park is nice for people watching. Nice area where there are lots of statues and art work.

Stopped by here around 9 pm after dinner to get a picture of the love sign lit up and we were made to feel very uncomfortable. There was a homeless man who immediately offered to take our picture with our phones. We politely declined but he was very insistent and constantly hovered over us promising that he wouldn’t steal our phones. We ended up taking pictures for another tourist couple and they did the same for us and the homeless man became quite aggressive as to why we wouldn’t let him take our picture. We were also approached by 2 other homeless people asking for money in the 10 minutes we were there. Unfortunately we could not fully enjoy the statue or the views of the surrounding buildings as we were made to feel very uncomfortable and somewhat threatened. Maybe we would have had a better experience during the day.

Interesting park with activities around.
Lots of people taking pictures with the love statue. There is another one Amor down the street.

There are many really cool statues in downtown philly and this one seems minor and somewhat out of place amongst all the cool historical sites to see. Nevertheless, if u r nearby, might as well take a quick photo but be aware, it’s really small and there’s likely a line
The park is nice. You can wait in line to get your picture with this art piece. Several other nearby items to see within walking distance.

I'm not sure what everyone else is expecting. I just wanted to see the LOVE sculpture and I was duly rewarded. From what our guide said, the park has been under renovation for the last year or two, so maybe that's why people have been so disappointed. As of August 2018, it's almost complete. All they have left to finish is the round building.
Don't know why people complain. It is what it is, you go up to it, take a picture, have someone take your picture and that's it. It's also not out of the way so there you have it.

I heard that this park was just redone so not sure what was there before. When we walked up, we couldn't believe how small the sign actually was. Not a long line and I still liked it, but it was not as big as I thought. Across the street we also did silly pictures with the big games pieces from Sorry an Monopoly and the big dominoes. Then we walked through city hall which was cool!

Even though there is no fountain anymore the love park is still the place to go to relax and enjoy watching people. Many activities happen there . There is also free games all day and of course the love sign

This is a very popular monument in Philly. To my disappointment, I learnt that they have scaled down the monument. It used to be huge but is much smaller than it once was. Nonetheless it’s still great for selfie opportunities
Love Park has gotten brighter and better since the construction. There is more space and more to do.
A lovely small park featuring the original LOVE sculpture. Plenty of places to sit and enjoy the surroundings and watch the little sparrows play.

During our visit, the LOVE sign was closed due to maintenance. On our way to Benjamin Franklin Museum, we hopped off (BIG BUS TOURS) to this very eye catching sign, AMOR. Also love in spanish, we just find it too cute not to have a photo with it. Love it!

We have enjoyed walking in this park during the daytime and also at night. We love it. Always fun to be here and of course taking our fotos at the LOVE statue! The water fountains are also fun to be around and watch the little kids (and big kids) play in them. A MUST when in the Philly area!

Philadelphia seems to have adopted Robert Indiana’s enigmatic LOVE statue with its lopsided “O” as its own since various editions exist throughout the city. The most prominent location is right across from City Hall in its own little LOVE Park on the Bank of America Plaza with City Hall and William Penn atop as well as the rest of Philadelphia at its feet. Another copy of the statue inspires passersby on the campus of the University of Pennsylvania where it competes for attention with the imposing sculpture of Benjamin Franklin seated on his high pedestal.

When I recently crossed LOVE Park around noontime intent on catching a suburban regional train underground, I felt compelled to stop and smile and watch children and their parents, a young couple and a group of school children reinforce their civic lesson by posing at the statue and having their photograph taken, sometimes by a complete stranger.

After all, Philadelphia is the City of Brotherly Love!

The Love park draws in many types of visitors ranging from locals, tourists, couples, families,friends,etc. Plenty of seating whether you just want to relax or soak in the peaceful vibes. I loved the fountains on such a cool day. Expect some lines if you want to take a picture under the love statue. You can also play ping pong and take some amazing shots of the city. You have panaramic views of the art musuem, major hotels,etc.

Went here during the thanksgiving weekend. It’s a small Christmas village. There’s all kinds of vendors from food to clothing to home and decors. It’s more of a German theme Christmas village. Try the bratwurst, pancake and the fries! Delicious! Then you go in the Kathe Wohlfahrt store! Full of Christmas decorations/ornaments! It’s a bit cold to go around so bundle up. Not a lot of area to sit around if u buy food or drink. It’s right across the city hall where there’s also more stalls.
Christmas village at Love park is so beautiful and romantic. great unique shops. I bought a handpainted ornament for my tree.

Took the train to Philly to go to Love Park. The city has an outdoor Christmas village with plenty of vendors selling everything from clothing, food, snacks and holiday gifts. Across the street in front of city hall are more vendors and the outdoor ice skating rink. The crowds weren't bad and the weather was cold but we just bundled up. It's a nice place to visit and walk around the city.

Not only can you get your picture taken under the famous love sign but this is a Christmas village with all sorts of arts and crafts and good beverages from local artisans. There's a couple of sections of this with a good mix of all of that and each part. There's even an ice skating rink. Great time, great Christmas shopping, great tourist attraction.

We visited Love park during their Christmas village display. Lots of shops and places to get a snack. After visiting Love park I suggest going across the street and visiting Macy's to see their light show and the Dickens village.

It’s such an iconic piece of art and so associates with Philly, of course you have to see it. It is smaller than I had thought. It’s so close to City Hall and other attractions, you owe it to yourself to make your Philly visit complete by seeing this little reminder of such a pure sentiment.

Just visited the park during the Christmas Village. Very nice walking through the stands and sampling foods, wines and seeing all the neat items for sale by varied vendors. Free event, and right next to City Hall.
I haven’t been in here in years up until 11-24-18. It is still super cute and a must see especially during the holidays!!

It's that time of the year again, they have just opened the xmas village at love park for the rest of the year, they have all sorts of German vendors, as well as other vendors. you can buy unique jewelry, all kinds of xmas Nic Nacs, good food, good fun for the whole family. if you are in town this is a must visit. merry xmas ! :-)
We love this sign! Got some good pictures and then when were in NYC after we found that one too but we liked this one better as you can stand under it.

I must be missing something here- what’s the big deal about a grassy area with the LOVE emblem? What goes on there? It’s behind (or us in front of) City Hall.

It’s certainly not “iconic,” tests for sure. And for the review that marvel led at seeing people from “four countries: how did that person know?

For me, the important point here is a memorial to the Holocaust/ the genocide of six million European Jews during World War II- see my photos.

I’ve always wanted to visit this park, and on a recent business trip I was able to stop by. The city view is captivating. There is so much to see with the neighboring buildings and architecture. Definitely a bucket list check off. Down the street they have an Amor sign- so cute! Same logo style.

Nice small garden. If its sunny, you will enjoy much more. You can walk to other nearby attractions from this park. Make it it a central parking location during your visit to the city. Parking is a problem. I suggest to go for a paid covered parking-house type of place and pay that $20-30 for the many hours you will spend there.

I was in town for a couple of days and had to check out this iconic attraction. The weather was great so there were several people in the park. Even though the park is in the center of a very busy city, it was as if we were on an island. I enjoyed seeing so many people of many varied ethnic backgrounds. In just the little time I was there I saw people from at least four other countries enjoying the views. It would have been nicer if the sign was bigger.
U can’t come to Philly w/o getting a cheesesteak, pretzel and visiting Love Park! It’s iconic and makes the ultimate Philly pic. Can get crowded depending on when u go.

The sign was...a LOT smaller than I thought it would be. Is there...is there another sign somewhere? (The German market around Christmastime was awesome, though! We hit the strudel tent like three times.)
It was redone and made smaller. I would still recommend checking it out. There is one not far from it in Spanish as well.

We went here the week before Christmas and it was a cute place! There are a lot of vendors selling various items (food, purses, ornaments, scarves, decorations etc). There was Christmas music playing, a small beer garden, photo ops with the "Love Park" sign and a band. I'm not sure what it is like when it is not Christmas but if you are there over the holiday, it's definitely worth a stop.

it’s nice to go and say you been but if you don’t go you didn’t miss anything. The sign it’s small and the park too, maybe when it’s not Christmas time it’s worse because they will not have Christmas lights and foods.

A great photo op is located at the Love Park sculpture. Depending upon when you go, you may have to wait in line. While waiting in line, feel free to talk to the locals. The visitors consist of local and non-local visitors.Love Park is an iconic stop. Suburban Station is located across the street. In addition to Love Park, there is a LOT to do in this area. Take advantage of the museums, murals, shops, and restaurants. There is a lot of FREE activities in this area, too.

My daughter spent an hour in the morning getting ready for the day of site seeing, just to take a pic in front of the Love sign.

It’s a must do activity while in Philly.

We returned in the evening in order to get nighttime pictures of the artwork. The LOVE sign is lighted at night. I thought the colors rotated, but it was only red on one side & green on the other the night we were there.

The Love sign is actually pretty small compared to what it looks like in pictures. It's also very busy and there was a line to get a picture. I am glad I saw it but I'm not sure I would go out of my way to see it again.
Our friend who met with us lives in Philadelphia. He tried to tell us that Philadelphia is the city of love, and this is one of its symbols. Naturally how many people knows these facts?

Constructed in aluminum, one of Robert Indiana's LOVE sculptures sits in John F. Kennedy Plaza for all the world to see since 1978. The original LOVE sculpture is on exhibit at the Indianapolis Museum of Art. This reproduction sculpture is actually a lot smaller than I anticipated, and much like its newly renovated park which it calls home, was nothing but a let down for me. I didn't feel like waiting for other visitors to get done checking it out to take my own picture so I didn't. I was also feeling sick. History reveals the joy of skateboarding was once had here until the city's "love" ordinance banned it from public property in 2003. After a recent renovation, the park from yesteryear is no more now replaced with a flat, sterile lifeless designed slab of concrete.
Stopped here with a friend to take pictures at the famous love statue. We had spent several hours walking around downtown Philly and this was one of our favorite photo ops.
This is a picture op and people line up to take pictures in front of the sign. But it is part of the Ben Franklin parkway which is a wonderful walk from the Art Museum to City Hall.
good place to visit some time in the afternoon and get clicked and remember the jews who died in the Halocaust . This park is a true symbol of this city's love of all around us!

The Love Park essentially is the Home to the Love statue. While there we stayed in line to take a picture below it. The line moved quickly and if the people behind you are nice enough they will take your picture with your loved one. I guess the reason you come here is to find Love which I guess I did. Did not see much of anything else; I’ve read reviews which talk about a fountain there but I did not see one in the winter time. Regardless we had fun and took great pics so it is all good

We come to Philadelphia every Christmas to visit relatives. We always stop at Christmas Village in Love Park! It’s so festive- music, lots of vendors and food, lights, large tree - great photo opts!! - beer garden, mulled wine, cheese haus, crafts, jewelry, ornaments, sweaters, art, purses - lot and lots of unique items!
Took my granddaughter here while we were visiting in Philly. She thought the love signs were awesome and played in the water fountains. This is a great place for touristy pictures.

Nice park for a photo op at the LOVE sign or I ❤️Philly sign. Worth a quick stop if in the area.
Place to sit and relax.
Great location for pictures of young children, college graduates and family groups. If you are within walking distance, do it !!

The “love sign” is cool but significantly smaller than you think. The “I Love Philly” sign is nearby and so is one that says “Amor”, which I found cooler than the Love sign for its irony. There is also an area with oversized board game pieces around the corner. All in all not much to write home about but still worth a walk over if you’re staying downtown. It’s also along the walk to the Rocky statue/stairs and the Rodin museum from City Hall so it’s an easy take in. Free, obviously.

The LOVE sign is significantly underwhelming, to-say-the-least. It's so small, and you stand underneath to take your pics. The park overall could be amazing if it had more food trucks, a bathroom, and put a stop to some random girl trying to sing. I think that my overall dislike for Philly carries over onto my salty attitude to this park as well. The water feature for the kids is pretty cool, and it a nice place, just expected more.

The view from that vantage point are underestimated. It feels like you are in the middle of everything. Though there was a line to take a picture everyone was patient and understanding. I would have paid for a professional photo and was surprised that wasn't an option.

Popular Love park~ There are seating area in this park, food cart vendor and the famous LOVE sign. Definitely an Instagram photo spot~ This park is located at a very busy area, near City Hall. In the day time, there are always police patrolling the area so less homeless people sleeping in the park.
This is one of my favorite parks. I liked the iconic statue and the ping pong table and other games. It's a really good place to take pics and its clean with lots of staff.
Very cute plaza with some great views and water fountains. Places to sit and relax also. Very cute photo op!!!

It’s neat for the photo op, but not as neat as you’d really want it to be. From a touristy perspective we did it cause its the cliche thing to do. If you are nearby, have a look and get in line to get a pic. But don’t go out of your way to see it.
We literally parked and ran out of the car to grab a family picture at this historic sculpture. So fun

The waiting line to get your picture under neath the sign could be long.

The point is not really the sign but more the plaza that give a great view in high rise building, old down town or other nice architecture
Fun stop for photo opportunities with the love sign and i heart philly sign. The splash pad was a hit with the kids. Nice place to sit and relax for a bit.

More than anything a great place for photos. Quick visit and well worth it. You may have to wait your turn for pictures with Love sign but it's ok. Work this stop into your agenda. You'll see the Love Statue in many Philadelphia pictures.

Surprised this is even listed as an attraction, because there isn’t much to see here. I guess folks like to have their picture taken in front of the Amor sign, but that’s the only attraction. Way better parks in Philly.
We walked here from our hotel. We enjoyed taking pictures with the LOVE sign and we enjoyed walking across the park to take pictures with the "I love Philly" sign.

I honestly don't know why people come here just to take a picture next to a silly insignificant sign. The traffic and parking in this city are terrible. We did several laps around this location and blocks near, and we were only able to find ONE parking space after 30 minutes of searching. One member of our party was handicap and had their handicap placard to place on the rear view mirror so we did, we parked, got down to take the picture and returned to see a parking ticket on our wiper. I think this city is too much trouble for what it is.

Cute park to visit to take photos as there is a couple of Love signs. Also noticed there was a water feature where kids could play in on hot summer days. Although surrounded by busy streets, the park seemed to be quiet and a nice place to relax and take in the citie's scenery.
Super place for photos. Right next to the tour bus stops. Easy in and out. Well maintained. Kids can play parents can relax.

This is a cool spot to walk through in town. It’s a great place to take photos. Locals will approach you to give them money for taking photos of you. At least they are offering a service and not just begging for money. There is a large homeless presence in the area but none of the people really bothered my friend and I even after sunset.
This is were you find the iconic "LOVE" sculpture for your bucket list trip to Philidelphia. An open air park just about a block northwest of City Hall it is an easy walk .

My husband basically dropped my sons and I off on the side of the road, we took pictures with Love Sign, and then we jumped back in the car. It looks like a nice park but being right in the middle of the city and with busy streets, finding parking to enjoy it might be difficult.

Cute sign, no one was around when we went there in the evening.
I saw the park and sign from a open bus and whilst with friends in their car. Definitely nothing special and you can just link it to a bus sight seeing trip.

This park was so pretty and the signs they had there were great. Had to wait a little bit for your turn to get a picture. People around there were really nice and willing to take your picture. So much fun!

This park is convenient located close to the city hall. The actual love sign and the Love Phili sign is, well, it’s there. There are chairs with ottoman that you can sit back and relax. There’s a water fountain, some people playing table tennis. It’s simply fun people watching as they hustle and bustle. For those driving a car, there is underground parking on the east side. Granted during Christmas time with all the decorations it’s gonna be beautiful. Best enjoyed by foot.

This was a difficult stop. It was rush hour and the traffic around the circle of Love Park was crazy. My husband actually dropped me and my oldest daughter off and had to drive in a circle around the park and pick us back up. The city makes a beautiful backdrop but it’s not an easy location to access.
Pretty park , people from all ages takes pictures with Love letters . I was expecting love letters bigger, more impressive.

Nice park to visit...it was raining loads but we didnt care...quick to visit
...to take some nice pictires and go to your next stop.

Lovely, romantic park. Visited both during the day and at night. You can't visit without taking a pic underneath the LOVE statue. But on a nice night, I highly recommend just taking a seat and enjoy the soothing, peaceful fountain.
It is amazing. Plenty to do. Nice water feature. I loved it. You should definitely visit love park.😀

Most of the research we did leading up to our trip to Philly included Love Park. It was a fun place to see, esp. before Christmas with all the vendors in place and the big "gift" displayed. Other than that, just a park near downtown

We walked through LOVE Park on our way from our hotel to the Rocky Steps. It is a nice, clean little park in the middle of downtown Philly. There were kids playing in the fountains and parents and young couples milling about. Several cute statues are spread throughout the city block-square park. Definitely a great place to take a break when walking around!

Having a picture in front of the “LOVE” sculpture is why you come to the Love Park. The park was dedicated in 1967 in remembrance to President John F. Kennedy, a.k.a. “JFK.”

The sculpture was designed in 1976 by Robert Indiana for Philadelphia’s 1976 Bicentennial. The sculpture became so popular that it became a permanent fixture.

The square is not very large. A fountain adds some life to the area that was once a skateboarding heaven. Politics took it away making way for a larger ceiling garage which is below your feet. The multi-level park is now just a single, mostly concrete, level with the “Love” sculpture being the major attraction.

A doable walk is the Academy of Natural Sciences; The Franklin Institute; Barnes Foundation and the Rodin Museum. A little further is the Philadelphia Museum of Art where Rocky ran up the 72 steps in the 1976 movie. The famous “Rocky” statue is to the right of the steps.

If you found this review to be “helpful” in any way, please press “LIKE” to let me know.

We got engaged at Love Park!! This is a great place to go and visit. In the summer time you can see people sitting around reading a book, enjoying the fountain, some homeless, and great to interact with others. It's a Philly place to see!!
This is a pretty average park but it does have the Philadelphia 'Love' statue. Worth a visit just so you can say 'been there, done that'.

Stopped at the Love Park Christmas Market. It's okay but if you have been to the Christmas Markets in Europe, it's a major let down. Lots of cheap junk but on the upside, there are a few quality vendors. The Mulled Wine was excellent as well as the food. Just know what you're looking for.
Very beautiful for the holiday. This one seems to be a photo opportunity more than anything else. Always like to stop here. Lots of vendors set up for the holiday.
Love Park is a wonderful place transformed into a German Christmas market. A lovely way to start the holiday season.
great view of downtown and Love sign and also another sign that says I Love Philly. always people waiting in line to take photos.
They redid this really nice, LOVE park Will always be a Philly monument. Great for pictures and an awesome the meet up point .
If you happen to be walking by, then by all means stop and take a photo. But I wouldn't go out of my way for this one.
Honestly, I really thought it was going to be a bigger park. Also surprised to see it was in the middle of downtown lol. Still very cool! And pretty!!!

Cute statue/art. Great for pictures. Sometimes very crowded. There are also “volunteers” there helping you take your picture. They actually want tips. Just FYI. Sometimes they have markets in the park as well.

I came here just for a photo of the Love sign.
There are lots of people taking photo under the sign.

Not worth going out of your way to see. It's in the middle of a busy square in traffic and it appeared you would have to pay parking in an underground lot just to go there and take a picture under the sign. Easy pass.
It doesn’t look much at all... and the sign is really small! Another one of those ‘I’ve walked through it’ places.

I had a quick work trip to Philadelphia area and I couldn't miss the opportunity to visit the Love Park, as I heard that area is a real good place to feel the city, take lots of pictures and don't forget to explore around!
Was awesome to see the Love Sculpture. It was the perfect photo opportunity. Lots of vendors with cool stuff.

Good place for couples to take a picture in front of the LOVE sign from Robert Indiana.
The queue for the picture might be long.

Always love this place. My office is 2 blocks from the area. During Christmas, this place becomes something else altogether. It becomes a hub of the Christmas village. Shops with souvenirs, various food and drink ( including crêpe, mulled wine or glowine, bratwurst, doner kebabs). Of course, the true essence still lies in the 'i love philly' structures. Diagonally opposite to this is the dillworth park - another attraction during Christmas time with light show on the City Hall and a skating rink for all ages to enjoy.

This park itself is nice but the nice thing about it is its location. Its close to the city hall and if the weather is nice, you get to have a long shot to take a picture through the Logan Square fountain all the way to the museum of art. The long shot will be beautiful, guaranteed.

We saw the symbol for the love park in all the gift shops so assumed it was a must see stop! It was small and not really worth the walk over! Stood there for a brief second for a photo that was it. Honestly, the board game park was much neater than this which is across cross the street.

Much smaller than we were expecting. We walked from our hotel to visit the park but once we got there we were a bit taken back about how small it was. It was cool and all just smaller than anticipated

Not sure I would go out of my way (even though we did) sculpture is rather small but good background and if you have to see sights that souvenirs are made out of, this is one of them. Several of these sculptures exist in certain cities. But can be a good romantic spot for a couple

Great park with nice scenery for an afternoon lunch. Parking below the park is pricey. Wish the LOVE statue was larger, or they had a stand to place your phone/camera to do a photo op in front of the statue.
Lots of police presence around the park. Lots of tables and chairs to sit and eat lunch or just hang out.

Great views and super pretty site.

A very small sculpture, but stands as an icon of Philly. It’s located downtown with parking available under the park. The parking is pretty expensive but the street parking is very limited. If you’re in the area it’s one to mark off the must-see.

Best visited when there are events, like an outdoor market or the annual Christmas Village. Otherwise, it's an open space with tables and chairs/benches and random people. The sign is a popular tourist spot so be prepared to wait your turn!

This wasn’t what I thought it would be. A tiny park in the middle of the city with parking below that’s overpriced for the underwhelming small LOVE sign. It’s ok if you really want to see it, if not... just drive by it. You’ll get the same effects as if you got out of the car. Didn’t waste time getting out to get a photo but I’m glad it’s marked off my bucket list needless to say.
Great ART, History for free, walking area leading to the museum of art. The city of Philadelphia offers great ART, and Festivities for couples and families alike

This park is situated at the bottom of Ben Franklin Pkwy between downtown and a view all the way out to the Art Museum. It is a great place for photos. The park has water features a copy of the iconic LOVE sculpture, and is a popular stopping place.
One of the iconic sculptures to visit when you come to Philadelphia! A beautiful plaza to explore and relax.
It isn't large; however, when you visit Philadelphia, Love Park with its iconic sculpture by the fountain is simply a must.

We went specifically for the Love sculpture. We got there about 2pm and were able to walk from Reading Terminal Market. We lucked out and there wasn't anyone else really by the sculpture so we had time to take a good amount of pictures/selfies. On the other end of the park was a water fountain area where kids were playing (it's meant to walk around in and get soaked). There is also an I heart Philly sign which is great for photos. Can get the fountain and City Hall in the background. Would recommend.
Very scenic and iconic cute stroll… YOU LITERALLY CANNOT go to Philly and not take a selfie in front of the love sign… ❤️❤️❤️❤️

How can you not “love” Love Park?

It’s a nice visit for couples to visit in Philadelphia

Getting a photo underneath the Love statue, I think, it’s a requirement for a happy marriage and relationship…

It’s a lot of fun go and enjoy
Right in the heart of downtown Philadelphia nice park where they can hold outside events and of course to see the iconic love sign

Although there isn't much there except the Love sculpture and the water features, it is at the center of so many things in Philadelphia. Open until 10pm, recommend going at night. Less crowds and the lights in the fountain and the city are wonderful.

Came to Philadelphia last weekend and fell in love with the city and especially this spot. Love Park has a great chilled atmosphere with kids jumping around. Love sign is a must when you visit the city. Like it very much
Anybody who flights to Philadelphia must stop at this park for the picture with the Love behind!!! It's a must :)
There is a water feature for toddlers to run through. It's a great place to walk around and take pictures. The love sign is the star
Luckily the Love Park was on the Big Bus route so we did not have to walk. The interesting fact we learnt about it was the father of Kevin Bacon had designed JFK Plaza in which the Love Park resides
A must for taking your photo. Don’t worry the people around will be eager to help you out. Remember it is the City of Brotherly w

The love messages of the Pop Art artist Robert Indiana can be found in many cities around the world - the first LOVE sculpture was installed in Indianapolis in 1970 and a copy of it can be found in the so-called Love Park in Philadelphia.
Would not waste your time to visit unless you are passing. The letters LO stacked on top of VE that are red. and that is it…………

We walked from the Museum of Art down Benjamin Franklin Pkwy to the centre and passed through here on the way. Only a small park which was snowy when we visited. It had a fountain although this was turned off due to the cold and there were lots of seats and tables out which would be nice in the summer. The Love sign is not massive but it was quiet when we visited so we got some photos with no one else in them which was good.

The public park was built in 1965 and covered an underground parking garage, it was dedicated in 1967 and officially named as John F. Kennedy Plaza after President John F. Kennedy. It is nick-named Love Park for its reproduction of Robert Indiana's 1970 sculpture being placed in the over-looking plaza in 1976 as part of the United States Bicentennial celebration. One of the features of the plaza became a centrally-located single spout fountain added in 1969. The area has a relaxed vibe and is also popular with skate boarders.

Location of the LOVE sign you can take pictures in front of. Parking is horrible street parking is limited; they have a parking garage cost us $20 for the 20 minutes we were there. Line for you to take your own pictures went quickly and everyone was very respectful. It's a small park with tables and a water display, there were no bathrooms that we could find.
I was expecting a big park but in reality it is very small. Apart from the emblematic LOVE, not much to do or see
there is a "LOVE" sign you can take picture, there are fountains, and you can take picture with City Hall as the background, very beautiful
Just a park. Has a nice fountain if kids want to run thru it. It's quiet and peaceful. I thought the love was smaller than I remembered.

Philadelphia’s iconic John F. Kennedy Plaza — better known as LOVE Park — is most famously the home of Robert Indiana’s iconic (and highly Instagrammable!) LOVE statue. Of course there are multiple versions of this famously loved art all around the world!
This version is smaller and elevated on a platform.

I was disappointed with Love Park and the iconic statue. With all the hype tied to this I expected more. The statue is small and is really just a photo op. If you are tight on time, go ahead and skip this.
Love Park is worth a quick stop when walking down Ben Franklin Parkway. Make sure to see the famous LOVE statue. Several other statues and fountains.
Bustling city square with lots of community events happening. Fun photo op with the "Love" sculpture. Great views of Ben Franklin Parkway between City Hall and Philadelphia Museum of Art

This is a walk through area but has a great view of City Hall. We enjoyed Philadelphia so much. It was clean and the people were very friendly and knowledgeable. They are gearing up for the 250th anniversary of the the US, so they are on point with everything. It is really such a beautiful city with so much to see! Our time at the end of April had perfect weather!

Love Park is an average open air urban park with the iconic "Love" sculpture in the middle. If you're walking past (it's near the iconic City Hall area), stop by so you can say you've seen it in person.
Did you even go to Philadelphia if you don’t stop here and take a picture? I don’t make the rules. It is a nice park by city hall in the middle of downtown.

A typical thematic sculpture in a beautiful relaxing park. Frequented by people wanting a photograph under the popula Love Sculpture.
Not necessarily a destination location but a stop in a featured area.
Love Park is no joke. It's even in the name. It's Love Park. A place for lovers to congregate and take pictures in Philly. Men, take your girlfriend to this jawn.

Was here with a reunion group. I was told it was a "must see". I don't agree with that, but it was okay to visit. The fountain was a hit. There's not much green space. We took pictures with the LOVE sign.
